150177496.review:
Even after all these years, LIMBO is still one of the greatest indie-game. It's hard to classify it: it's a platformer, but it will rarely require good timing; it's a puzzle game, but you won't spend hours trying to figure out solutions; it's a horror game, but there's no blood, no jumpscare, not even fear, just a disturbing atmosphere.

I wouldn't recommend this game if someone asked me to suggest a platformer, a puzzle game or a horror game. But for someone asking for something new and/or looking for a game with a peculiar atmosphere, I wouldn't hesitate one second. PLAY THIS GAME! It's classics!

149969130.review:
It's not a terrible game, and I can see why people enjoyed it, but the atmosphere and the gameplay clashed in a way that really ruined both for me.

The silhouette style is iconic and does a lot of the heavy lifting building a creepy atmosphere, but it also severely limits the information that the game can communicate to the player, which can be a problem in a puzzle game. There are a number of puzzles where it would be unreasonable to expect the player to figure out how to solve them without dying once or twice just to figure out how they worked. This made character death feel like less of a punishment, and more like just another tool to progress the game. Once death became a routine part of advancing the game, the whole creepy vibe sort of fell apart.

For anyone who's looking at this game because of that creepy atmosphere, I would strongly suggest Inside. It's by the same developer/publisher (Playdead), and while I think the puzzles in that game are a bit simpler, it does a far better job of maintaining a creepy atmosphere for the duration of the gameplay.

149952615.review:
30/100 utterly tedious, thousands of insta-deaths and frustrating trial and error.  Play Cocoon or Inside instead, and skip this one entirely.

I finished Cocoon first, then finished Inside, then played Limbo.  I am quitting after 4 hours at chapter 19 of 24, at the cart with the headlight, and will never finish this game as it's just a really bad game.  Cocoon is the best of the three, with logical puzzles.  Inside is kind of ok but not as good as Cocoon.  In other words the games in this series are getting better as they go, and this one is the earliest and the worst.  It's like how some early adventure games relied on pixel hunting for their puzzles - it was frustrating and no fun to play.  This game fails to clearly signal what you need to do, and delights in just killing you repeatedly.  It's not so much puzzles as trial and error precise platforming and just repeatedly trying slightly different placements of a cog or cart before making a jump.  

Forget the hype over the unique art style, this is not a game, it's just tedium.

149873033.review:
LIMBO is a reminder that games don't need to be grandiose to be a banger. It's a 2D puzzle-platformer, but calling it that wouldn't be doing the game justice. The game doesn’t bother with a tutorial, trusting you enough to figure out its physics-based puzzles on your own.

The soundscape is minimal but haunting. Every sound serves a purpose, and the dark droning ambiance does more than any soundtrack could. LIMBO's puzzles and level design are clever, with some very rewarding "Aha" moments scattered throughout the 3-4 hour experience. It is a trial-and-error fest that will see the boy meet his end in the most gruesome ways. You learn, you adapt, and you die, often to the game's morbidly creative traps.

LIMBO is an experience that doesn't coddle you, but instead throws you into the deep end of its dark, minimal, and violent world and watches what you'll do.

149402889.review:
The level of pixel-perfect millisecond-precise platforming the game requires is unfortunately not matched by equally good controls, which are slow, dragged and 'slippery' in comparison. I think the decision to make jumping and climbing a ladder the same button was a major mistake which really contributed to the clunky platforming.

The trial-and-error cycle of getting killed a dozen times until you can even get the chance to see the entirety of a puzzle ahead of you is also a bit annoying. Maybe a kind of a zoom-out or look-ahead feature could have been considered instead.

These two hurdles unfortunately made the game quite unpleasant for me, even though I really really liked the art style and the overall atmosphere. This is obviously a studio of very talented and capable developers and artists (I'm in love with their second game, Inside), but this one was, unfortunately, just not up to my taste.

149280225.review:
I played this when it released on PS3 in 2011 and have always looked back at it as a really good game but now having played it again, maybe because I've become more analytical and critical, I found it really hard to enjoy for most of the game. 
It has a very unique visual style, very basic gameplay, good sound and atmosphere, a very strange story that is more show than tell, the big spider never fails to make me feel weird because of how squishy it is and how it moves and the final part of the game is great but all the way up to that point is pretty bad.

It is designed in a way that forces you to use trial and error to figure things out and I counted 6 separate points where you have a 0.5 second window to do the right thing or you die. 
Even though I have played it three or so times before there were still several points where I just forgot what happens and died because of it. Something that makes it even more frustrating is that rather than looking ahead and acting based on what you see you are meant to wait for something to happen and then react immediately, which goes against all logic in the moment, and if you don't react fast enough or you try to do something logical you die and have to do it again.

In the end it's just not fun or engaging until the last section and although it does have a few interesting puzzles throughout it, it doesn't hold the game up very high against the core design issue.

149214639.review:
[h3] Limbo commits fully to minimalism, perhaps to a fault. [/h3]

Directional arrows aside, Limbo only has two other inputs: Jump and use. The game begins without any cutscenes or context. There is no colour, only shades of black and white. Annoyingly, there are no accessibility or graphics options in the menu. This dichotomy represents the best and worst that Limbo has to offer. 

Limbo’s use of black, which typically makes up 1/3 of the screen, encourages the player’s imagination to fill in the gaps. Just enough is shown, whether through blurry perimeters of trees or machinery, to allude to an outside world. This means simple objects often invite the player to extract deeper meanings. One chapter shows a single person, rope around their neck, hanging solemnly from a tree in the background; an easy detail to miss, but one which suggests a dysfunctional world outside the player’s understanding.

Gameplay toes the line between accessible and perhaps too simple. When you boil it down, Limbo is mostly jumping puzzles with the occasionally pushing and dragging of an object. This means it’s easy to pick-up yet deceptively headscratching at times. By the end, you’re still mostly jumping, mainly during narrower windows of opportunity, and little else is really added. You can swing from ropes using your momentum, and that’s really it.

On the one hand, this simplicity is a love letter to the basics of gaming. However, there isn’t much of a sandbox to play around with. There’s no level editor, and the game is a brisk 4 hours – maybe 3 if you’re smarter than I was. Limbo launched during the initial batch of Xbox 360 arcade titles in the late 2000s, and while visually it’s the polar opposite to titles like Castle Crashers, it doesn’t feel as developed gameplay-wise as even those rudimentary button mashers. 

It’s worthwhile if you’re into 2D platformers to play one of the modern classics of the genre, especially given its pivotal contribution to the rise of indie publishers in the digital era. But its dedication to keeping things simple unsurprisingly leads to a very basic game that’s largely been built superseded nowadays, albeit on the foundations it created.

148675935.review:
[i]Played this before INSIDE and Cocoon[/i]

I…don't know what to rate this?

Limbo is a haunting, brutal and unforgiving experience. Such a dark and rich atmosphere that shrouds this disturbing world in a black and white static haze, leaving a lot up to the imagination, working wonders for the games striking imagery. The small glowing eyes of the Boy, a leg of a spider poking out of the overgrown wild. Mirroring the world, the gameplay is harsh; many unforgiving jumps and timings and traps that seem impenetrable, doing everything they can to keep you from progressing.  However, a lot of the puzzles can be tedious, there’s some very precise timing and platforming needed and a lot of the deaths in the game can seem cheap, especially as you can’t see a lot of them coming.

But maybe that's the point? The world Limbo drags you down into is dark and oppressing, around every corner there's death. This boy fucking DIES. Like from basically anything and everything. Over and over again. Again the visual design elevates this imagery, with your mind filling in the details left from the simple graphics, almost protecting you from seeing and experiencing what this boy is going through. Stuck in a constant loop, a purgatory, learning and slowly you overcome all of this darkness, crawling out of the endless cycle, this limbo...

Many, MANY thoughts and a few mixed feelings about this. The story is simple on the surface, but through the obtuse storytelling and even just writing this review I can't stop thinking about it and all the theories and questions I have. 

Spoiler territory (conclusion under):
[spoiler] Seen people think the conclusion is underwhelming or wondering what the point of the game is? I adore how ambiguous this story is, and I hope everyone can come up with their own conclusions. I see this as a very bittersweet story. The ending shows the boy’s sister burying him. The boy pushes on through Limbo, conquering his fears until the very end where his final fear is conquered; his sister's safety. Yes he cannot come back to her, but just knowing she’s okay allows him to move on. 
There is a LOT I want to say and dive into, but gonna save it while I think about this game and potentially replay it in the future. [/spoiler]

Limbo has had a really weird effect on me and I'm struggling to place my feelings about it, but all I can say is I definitely recommend this. I am looking forward to seeing how the team evolves in the coming games, and maybe after a replay of this is needed. Definitely needed to process this a bit before coming up with my feelings about it. ★★★★☆ 4/5

148454293.review:
Limbo is the gaming equivalent of a very well-written short story. It has a very specific purpose, it executes its purpose flawlessly, and it doesn't over-stay its welcome. Every single piece of Limbo fits together seamlessly to create an experience that makes up for its brevity by packing a punch.

And just like good short stories, Limbo won't be everyone's cup of tea. You have to really enjoy puzzle games to appreciate Limbo. You also need to appreciate atmospheric visuals and audio, because Limbo has only one aesthetic.

I loved the brief time I spent on Limbo, even if I thought one or two of the puzzles were very un-fair.

9/10

148425446.review:
[h1]A Solid Artsy Platformer That is Worth Playing...[/h1]
[i]... when it goes on sale. Yeah, [b]Limbo[/b] may be a very pretty little two to three hour work of monochrome art, but it has virtually no replay value other than a couple collectibles that uncover a secret which reveals... next to nothing about the plot. There is also an achievement for beating this game with less than five deaths, but that is practically impossible unless you've finished the game already or are following a guide very closely. Every area you enter in this game plays out like this:

"Wow this is a pretty, noir looking- wait what?! I just got crushed/skewered/crucified/burned/shot/eaten/drowned/electrified/blown up/smothered/forced to watch Keemstar's entire catalog of videos??? How the hell was I supposed to see that until it was right on top of me?"

Then you know that thing will kill you, you try again to avoid, usually succeed unless the weighty and physics based platforming is having a weird stimming break, and you press on. It's not absurdly difficult, the game is quite short after all, but there are few games that are the definition of trial and error like [b]Limbo[/b] is. If you're ok with dropping dead every couple minutes and then quickly respawning to solve the puzzle, this game could be quite satisfying for you. But the deaths in this game somehow manage to be both obnoxious and yet also inconsequential. It's like the game has an obligation to kill you without any consequence on your end, as if you're Prometheus and this game is the eagle.

Nobody can deny how utterly gorgeous this game is, but also how amazing the sound work is. Not talked about often with this game, but the atmospheric tracks do a good job of hinting at key areas that contain puzzle solutions, industrial chimes, foreboding hums for incoming danger, the list is endless. Although the monochrome color scheme can frustrate with how little anything in the environment is telegraphed, it still is beautiful. Lighting, shadows, and animation honestly all belong in a museum they're so great.

So if you are up for less than a handful of hours of good atmosphere and presentation, somewhat weak puzzles, and questionable deaths then [b]Limbo[/b] is certainly worth drowning in. Or burning in. Or exploding in. Or getting sliced in. Or crushing in. Or-[/i]

148229146.review:
Honestly, I'm very impressed, and I strongly recommend playing the game. 
Before deciding on the purchase, I read many reviews hailing this game as a must-have for a lover of puzzle platformers, and after buying the game and playing it through: yes - I fully agree.

The number of different puzzles with just a few basic mechanics (jump, push/pull, traps/circular saws, gravity change and world rotation) is staggering. On top of that, the creepy atmosphere truly isn't praised for nothing. Music? Perfectly both hair-raising and calming, depending on what the particular chapter requires. And animations? I'm sold, especially by the precise death animations and the disturbing cut scenes.

And to finish off the strong start, nothing in the whole complexity annoyed me. The physics actually worked the way intended and hand in hand with the animations, and both the number and difficulty of the achievements were just right. I have nothing to complain about.

Therefore, the game is unquestionably worth the money, even with the playtime itself not being that long (a bit less than three hours for a run with all secrets, and then one and half more for a run without deaths making it four and half hours in total).

10/10

148030264.review:
Limbo is an uncompromising, difficult, puzzle game. A game I forced myself to complete hoping that as I understood the mechanics more, my angst with the game would subside. It did not.

I truthfully did not understand the story. Who is this girl? Do I save her? Am I supposed to be with her? Is she my grieving mother? Did she have to go through these ridiculous traps just to get here? Who are these natives with spears? Do the hidden eggs have any meaning? What's the significance of the HOTEL sign? Who invented these anti-gravity devices? Am I venturing through my subconscious or past memories trying to avoid the symbolic traps life throws at you? Don't know! ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

As I ventured through each area it felt like I was being subjected to a series of Grimtooth's Traps. Each area became a lesson in aggravation. Enter area, look around, see no clues how to solve this area, die, possibly die again, definitely die again on puzzles that require you to time events, have epiphany. "Oh, so that's what I'm supposed to do, ok, but why would I know to do that?" Don't know! ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I understand the hardcore players will proclaim, "Skill issue, git gud!" and I can understand their ridiculous proclamation. I really wanted to like, enjoy, and have the emotional experience that other reviewers wrote about. I, unfortunately, could not get there. This is just not the game for me even though I hoped it would be.

148010537.review:
[h1]Una oscura odisea en las sombras[/h1]
LIMBO es un juego indie que cautiva desde el principio con su atmósfera única y su estilo visual distintivo. En esta experiencia minimalista, te encuentras atrapado en un oscuro y misterioso mundo, enfrentándote a una serie de puzzles y desafíos para avanzar. En una época dónde paso de varios juegos, LIMBO llega a mi vida para hacerme recordar el interés de lograr hacerse con alguna meta, sentir el temor de 'perder una vida', disfrutar los pequeños detalles.

[u]Razones para hacerte con este juego:[/u]
[list]
[*][b]Estilo visual inmersivo:[/b] La estética de LIMBO es impresionante y única. El juego se representa en blanco y negro, con tonos de grises y sombras profundas, lo que crea una atmósfera sombría y opresiva que te sumerge por completo en su universo.

[*][b]Diseño de acertijos ingenioso:[/b] Los acertijos en LIMBO son inteligentes, desafiantes y se integran perfectamente en el entorno. Requieren pensamiento lateral y experimentación para resolverlos, lo que proporciona una satisfacción genuina cuando encuentras la solución. Eso sí, el nivel de complejidad al momento de la ejecución va en picada, es decir, lo complicado está al inicio, poco a poco se vuelve monótono y predecible.

[*][b]Narrativa sugerida:[/b] LIMBO cuenta su historia de una manera no convencional, sin diálogos ni explicaciones directas. En cambio, la narrativa se sugiere a través del entorno y la secuencia de eventos, lo que fomenta la interpretación personal y la inmersión en el mundo del juego.

[*][b]Logros:[/b] Una vez que completas LIMBO y resuelves los acertijos, es posible que la motivación para volver a jugar sea 0 (como es mi caso), por lo que recomendaría encarecidamente darte una ojeada a los logros, una lista corta pero certera, más que todo uno en específico que te hará tomarte de los pelos y vivirás con las emociones a tope, recomendado una vez logrado terminar el juego.
[/list]

[hr][/hr]
LIMBO es una joyita indie que cautiva con su estilo visual único y su narrativa grotesca. Con acertijos inteligentes que desafían la mente y una estética cautivadora, ofrece una experiencia de juego inolvidable. A pesar de su corta duración, la experiencia y la satisfacción de haberlo jugado y haberse hecho con todos los logros bien valen la inversión. Si te gustan los juegos de rompecabezas atmosféricos y estás buscando algo fuera de lo común, definitivamente se recomienda la compra de LIMBO.

147758360.review:
I feel bad for giving Limbo a negative review because I can totally see why its gotten so much praise over the past decade. Unfortunately, I rate the games that I play based on my own personal enjoyment and unfortunately I didn't have very much enjoyment playing this game.

 Let's get the most obvious and well known out of the way first. Limbo, as simplistic looking as it is, is a very beautiful game. The entire game is in black, white, and grey. There are no hints of bright colors anywhere, but somehow it manages to look beautiful. I played it on my Steam Deck and everything from the backgrounds to animations was very pleasing to the eye. The visuals as well as the sound made for a very haunting atmosphere, which suits October especially well.

 Limbo is a side scrolling platformer with a main focus on puzzles and this is where it falls flat for me. To be honest I don't play puzzle games often and when it comes to puzzles in other genres, I am not very good at them. The problem is not that I'm dumb or anything, but I'm just very impatient. I will try a puzzle 3 or 4 times and after that I go straight to a guide because I feel that tedious repetition is a waste of time. With that said, I feel that its only partly my fault why I didn't enjoy Limbo. First of all, the game does not explain anything at all. It's far from a complex game as it only uses two buttons for jump and push/pull, as well as an analog stick to walk. However there is no HUD or tutorial of any kind. You press start and you're right in the game. Figure it all out. I don't mind this approach because it adds to the mystique atmosphere of the game, but it also doesn't explain its own rules. I think that understanding the rules is very important when completing puzzles. Limbo is almost entirely based on trial and error. Many of the puzzles I felt like I had to purposely die in order to see what would happen so that I can know what's allowed and what's not in each particular area. Imagine if you took a multiple choice test, and you had infinite attempts. Sooner or later you will get the correct answer, even if its the last one you choose, and even though you finally get to move on to the next question, you didn't pass the previous question due to your intelligence, but rather because you've tried everything else. In the second half of the game I felt like I needed to use a video guide for almost every section and to me that was not fun. I didn't have a sense of accomplishment. True, its my fault for looking it up, but like I said earlier, time is valuable and I often felt like this game was wasting my time.

On the plus side this game is very short and can be completed in one sitting. It also has pretty forgiving checkpoints so I give it props for that. Again, take my review with a grain of salt. Context is very important here and even though I didn't enjoy the game, I can still totally see why some people view this game as one of their all time favorites.

147701253.review:
Limbo, released in 2011 by the Danish indie developer Playdead, is a game that defies easy categorization. It stands as a stark and mesmerizing example of the power of minimalism in video game design. With its hauntingly beautiful black-and-white visuals, eerie ambient soundscape, and cleverly crafted puzzles, Limbo offers an unforgettable and emotionally charged gaming experience.

Visually, Limbo is a marvel. Its monochromatic, silhouetted aesthetic creates a sense of otherworldly beauty and dread simultaneously. The game's minimalist approach to graphics manages to convey a sense of depth and atmosphere that few other titles can match. The stark contrast between light and shadow serves as a metaphor for the game's thematic exploration of life and death.

Limbo's gameplay is equally minimalist but incredibly effective. You control a young boy who awakens in a nightmarish forest and embarks on a perilous journey to find his sister. The controls are simple - move, jump, and interact - yet the game manages to present increasingly complex challenges. Puzzles in Limbo often require precise timing and lateral thinking, but they never feel frustratingly obtuse. The trial-and-error gameplay encourages experimentation and rewards players for their persistence.

One of the game's most striking aspects is its approach to storytelling. Limbo eschews traditional narrative exposition and dialogue, instead opting for environmental storytelling and symbolism. The game invites players to interpret its haunting world and story for themselves, creating a deeper connection to the protagonist's plight. This ambiguity adds to the game's sense of mystery and unease, leaving players with lingering questions long after the credits roll.

The audio design in Limbo deserves special mention. The ambient soundscape is hauntingly beautiful, with every footstep, creaking tree, and ominous hum contributing to the game's eerie atmosphere. It's a masterclass in audio immersion and adds immeasurably to the overall experience.

Limbo is not without its criticisms. Some players may find the game's length a bit short, as it can be completed in a few hours. Additionally, some might argue that the puzzles can occasionally feel repetitive. However, these issues are minor in the grand scheme of things, as the brevity of the experience ensures that it remains consistently engaging from start to finish.

In conclusion, Limbo is a true work of art in the world of video games. Its minimalist design, breathtaking visuals, and enigmatic storytelling combine to create an unforgettable and emotionally resonant experience. While it may not be a lengthy adventure, its impact is undeniably profound. Limbo is a game that lingers in the mind long after you've completed it, and it stands as a testament to the artistic potential of the medium. If you appreciate games as an art form and are willing to embark on a journey into the unknown, Limbo is an essential experience that should not be missed.

Enter area, look around, see no clues how to solve this area, die, possibly die again, definitely die again on puzzles that require you to time events, have epiphany. "Oh, so that's what I'm supposed to do, ok, but why would I know to do that?" Don't know! ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I understand the hardcore players will proclaim, "Skill issue, git gud!" and I can understand their ridiculous proclamation. I really wanted to like, enjoy, and have the emotional experience that other reviewers wrote about. I, unfortunately, could not get there. This is just not the game for me even though I hoped it would be.

LIMBO es un ejemplo magistral de cómo un videojuego puede contar una historia profunda y conmovedora sin necesidad de palabras. Desde el momento en que comienzas a jugar, te sumerges en un mundo oscuro y misterioso que te atrapa por completo.

El estilo artístico en blanco y negro de LIMBO es verdaderamente sobresaliente. Cada escenario está meticulosamente diseñado, y los detalles en las sombras y la iluminación crean una atmósfera única y evocadora. Cada cuadro del juego podría ser una obra de arte en sí mismo.

La ausencia de diálogo o texto escrito es un enfoque audaz que permite a los jugadores interpretar la historia a su manera. Esto fomenta la reflexión y la exploración, ya que debes descubrir por ti mismo los misterios del mundo de LIMBO.

La jugabilidad es intuitiva pero desafiante, con rompecabezas ingeniosos que te obligan a pensar de manera creativa. La dificultad del juego se siente justa y nunca frustrante, lo que te permite avanzar a través de la historia de manera fluida.

La música y los efectos de sonido son igualmente destacados, contribuyendo a la atmósfera inquietante y a veces melancólica del juego.

Charming puzzle platformer that can be completed in 1-2 sittings. Very much an early ‘artsy’ game with gorgeous visuals and simple gameplay. 

The narrative being you are looking for your sister, but it is very much up to your interpretation what is going on during your journey.

Gameplay is platforming and puzzles, which become a little frustrating towards the end where perfect timing is required, but it never gets overly difficult. You run, jump or push/pull objects and activate the occasional leaver.

146015990.review:
LIMBO may be one of the most overrated games I've ever played.

As a puzzle game, it's an abject failure. Well constructed puzzles should communicate a goal and ask the player the deduce a solution. Instead, LIMBO's puzzles often obscure the goal, and are usually solved by simply figuring out what you can interact with. There are no options, so there are no incorrect solutions. This is more frustrating than it sounds, as Limbo's artsy aesthetic and inconsistent logic mean that its rarely clear how you might interact with a puzzle. The result is that most puzzles are exercises in trial and error.

Even when a solution is apparent, the execution can be unreasonably demanding. Very tight timing and perfect accuracy are often required, and the platforming and physics of the game do not lend themselves to precision.

LIMBO's visuals are elegantly simple, although they often fail to communicate necessary information to the player. At times, LIMBO dabbles in "gotcha" design, punishing players for believing that it will behave consistently or using visual cues to mislead the player. The audio is effective, if stark.

Overall, this is just a subpar puzzle game. I can only believe that the style of the game blinded reviewers to its shortcomings. At less than 5 hours to complete, LIMBO still manages to outstay it's welcome.

Lo recomiendo! 

Cosas que comentar:

Artísticamente está muy cuidado. La estética minimalista, la ausencia de colores y el sonido ofrecen una experiencia inmersiva en un mundo oscuro y cruel.

El plataformeo es bastante mediocre, y quizás un poco torpe, pero los puzles están bastante bien. No son para nada repetitivos, por lo que exigen prestar mucha atención para ingeniar cómo resolverlos. El diseño de niveles, en general, es muy bueno. Pocos elementos visuales son suficientes para guiar la atención del jugador.

No está clara cuál es la historia, pero claramente es la intención del juego. En mi opinión, es una virtud. Hay muchas interpretaciones posibles de lo que está ocurriendo.  Personalmente me gusta pensar que es una historia sobre cómo el  amor es lo único que nos tranquiliza en un mundo plagado de hostilidades (la naturaleza, los humanos, las máquinas). Un punto que me gusta del juego es que nosotros no somos necesariamente mejores que ninguna de esas hostilidades. A fin de cuentas, acabamos con la vida de muchas criaturas, algunas de las cuales nos eran claramente hostiles, y otras que no lo parecían tanto.

145829640.review:
[h1] Limbo: A Haunting Journey into Darkness [/h1]

Limbo, developed by Playdead, is a mesmerizing and hauntingly beautiful puzzle-platformer that takes players on a dark and atmospheric journey through a mysterious and perilous world. Released in 2010, it remains a classic in the indie game genre.

Set in a monochromatic, grayscale environment, Limbo immediately immerses you in its eerie and unsettling atmosphere. The lack of color adds to the sense of foreboding, making every shadow, trap, and creature you encounter all the more menacing. The game's minimalist art style is nothing short of breathtaking, with meticulously detailed backgrounds and character animations that evoke a sense of both beauty and dread.

The narrative in Limbo is intentionally cryptic and open to interpretation. You control a young boy who awakens in a dark forest and embarks on a perilous quest to find his sister. The absence of dialogue or text prompts encourages players to piece together the story themselves, adding an extra layer of immersion. It's a tale of innocence and vulnerability set against a backdrop of cruelty and danger.

Gameplay in Limbo revolves around solving a series of environmental puzzles and avoiding deadly traps. The puzzles are cleverly designed and often require both logic and timing to overcome. Death in Limbo is frequent and often gruesome, but it serves as a learning experience rather than a punishment. Each death provides a clue or teaches a lesson, encouraging experimentation and perseverance.

What truly sets Limbo apart is its ability to evoke a wide range of emotions. The sense of isolation and unease is palpable, yet there are moments of beauty and even tenderness amidst the darkness. The game's sound design plays a crucial role, with subtle ambient sounds and an evocative soundtrack that heighten the overall experience.

Limbo is a relatively short game, but its impact is long-lasting. It's a masterpiece of atmospheric storytelling and puzzle design, offering a unique and unforgettable gaming experience. If you're looking for a game that will challenge your intellect, evoke strong emotions, and stay with you long after the credits roll, Limbo is a must-play title in the world of indie gaming.

145713931.review:
Limbo is a visual masterpiece, and its seamless monochrome presentation will forever be its most talked-about facet. It's also a competent puzzle-platformer, though sometimes marred by frustration. The worst offences are when its emotional moments or big setpieces are undermined by its trial-and-error nature, Despite its short length, I was a bit relieved when the chapter list showed that I was nearing the end of the game, as I didn't know how many more times I could sit through its wonderfully grisly death animations. 

However, once I reached the end I felt fulfilled. This despite there being no narration. Limbo does an admirable job of manipulating the player's emotions through its contextual storytelling and excellent sound design. I'm fairly certain the developers didn't have a clue what the story is about. But so what? Noel Gallagher doesn't know what Champagne Supernova is about either, and he wrote the bloody song.

Generations from now, Limbo will still stand as aesthetically timeless. A tale told entirely in silhouette, its visuals are a stroke of genius. Its lack of words lets players have an abundance of feeling. This is an extremely pretty game, and a very artsy one. Limbo is the title that pretentious hacks like Jonathan Blow [i]wish[/i] they had made.

143912964.review:
Un Viaje Oscuro e Inolvidable: Limbo

Gráficos (5/5): Limbo es un ejemplo sobresaliente de cómo los gráficos minimalistas pueden ser increíblemente efectivos. Presentado en blanco y negro con sombras sutiles, el juego crea una atmósfera opresiva y sombría que sumerge al jugador en un mundo desconocido y peligroso. Los detalles en el diseño de los personajes y el entorno, aunque simples, son impactantes. Cada escena se siente como una obra de arte cuidadosamente compuesta.

Historia y Narrativa (4.5/5): Limbo es una experiencia misteriosa y sin diálogos que se basa en la interpretación del jugador. Sigues la historia de un joven niño en busca de su hermana perdida en un mundo hostil y surrealista. La narrativa se desarrolla de manera sutil a través de los eventos del juego y los elementos visuales, lo que permite que cada jugador cree su propia interpretación de la historia. Este enfoque no convencional en la narración es refrescante y desafiante.

Jugabilidad (4.5/5): Limbo es un juego de plataformas y resolución de acertijos en su forma más pura. Los desafíos son inteligentes y a menudo mortales, lo que te obliga a experimentar y aprender de tus errores. La simplicidad de los controles, con solo unos pocos botones para moverte y saltar, se convierte en una ventaja, ya que te permite concentrarte en la resolución de los intrincados acertijos. La dificultad es elevada pero gratificante.

Sonido y Música (5/5): La banda sonora minimalista y los efectos de sonido contribuyen significativamente a la atmósfera del juego. Los susurros inquietantes y los ruidos ambientales añaden tensión a cada paso que das en el mundo de Limbo. La música, compuesta por Martin Stig Andersen, es sublime en su simplicidad y profundidad emocional.

Conclusión (4.5/5): Limbo es una obra maestra del diseño de juegos independientes que desafía las convenciones y ofrece una experiencia única. Su estilo visual distintivo, su narrativa intrigante y su jugabilidad desafiante lo convierten en un título imprescindible para cualquier amante de los videojuegos. Aunque su duración es relativamente corta, su impacto emocional perdura mucho después de haberlo terminado. Si buscas un viaje oscuro y conmovedor en el mundo de los videojuegos, Limbo es una elección sobresaliente.

143808641.review:
Overall, it's a good game, but I found too many shortcomings; therefore, it doesn't deserve the real recommendation. I'm somewhere in the middle, but it's a thumb down from me.

I'll start with the things that I actually liked about LIMBO.
First of all... the ambiance and sound design. You can really feel immersed in this title just by wearing headphones and letting the ambiance play for a while. It can be loud and unsettling, but also gentle and quiet when needed.

Next is level design (some of them, to be exact). The level designers did a good job in creating interesting and often non-obvious puzzles. Most of the time, they place us in an area with only a few objects, which really forces us to think.

There are also things that, in my personal opinion, are not really good, or sometimes even bad.
The main thing that bothers me is the later part of the game, specifically its difficulty and checkpoint placement.
The perfectly timed puzzles were cool as long as they didn't result in death, requiring you to walk all the way back to where you died. The idea is good, but the execution falls short.

In conclusion
Pros:
- Sound design
- Atmosphere
- Creative puzzles (most of them)
- Interesting world-building

Cons:
- Difficulty in the later stages of the game
- Checkpoint placement
- Ending

I expected something more, but it's still a cool game to buy (only on sale!).

How Long To Beat was right for this title and my completion time has fallen within expectations, not that I was rushing or anything but it is interesting how it compares to others times.

Limbo is best experienced blind, it is a puzzle game and a platformer. Nothing is really super hard, only a couple of devilish puzzles were teasing me. Some sort of leech is over-played in this, you have to exploit its visible weakness and natural predator to remove it but they attach at specific points in the journey and just bug me, it is not hard though.

I've played Inside before this and both are very good, I do put Inside higher up because the journey and movement is more organic, it also feels more intuitive whereas Limbo is like huh I died let me just keep doing this until I notice something different... or at least that's what it was for me near the end.

Awesome experience and I can't shelve it yet, but for now at least I am content to leave my progress with it where it is. Recommended for the atmosphere, the puzzles and the platforming, also as players know the movement has to not be janky and here there's some float feeling to the character but otherwise it's fairly solid.

143216188.review:
In the realm of gaming, where frenetic action and dazzling graphics often dominate, there exists an atmospheric, minimalist gem that leaves an indelible mark on the canvas of your memory. This game is none other than Playdead's critically acclaimed masterpiece, LIMBO.

At first glance, one could be deceived into thinking that LIMBO is a simple platformer, but it transcends that genre and blossoms into something much more. It is a grand tapestry of art, philosophy, and storytelling, carefully woven together into an unforgettable gaming experience.

The graphics, while seemingly minimalist, are a study in thoughtful artistry. The monochromatic, silhouetted visuals render the game's environment with an eerie beauty that is both captivating and haunting. The intricate design of each level, laden with layered shadows and infused with a sense of melancholic charm, not only elicits a sense of desolation but also of fascination. It's a testament to the adage, "less is more".

LIMBO's eerie, soundless soundtrack enhances its mysterious ambiance, inviting the player to become fully immersed in the world around them. The lack of music heightens the player's senses, creating a raw and unnerving atmosphere that is perfectly synced with the visuals.

The gameplay is marked by clever and innovative puzzles, each with its own unique twist, effectively testing the player's ingenuity and quick reflexes. The controls are perfectly calibrated, simple and responsive, allowing players of all experience levels to navigate with ease through the shadowy world.

What really sets LIMBO apart is its ability to tell a poignant and emotionally resonant story without the use of dialogue or text. Through carefully crafted animations, subtle visual clues, and evocative gameplay mechanics, it weaves an ambiguous yet touching narrative of a little boy's quest to find his lost sister, leaving players to draw their own conclusions and interpretations.

While LIMBO does tread on dark themes and delivers a fair share of tense, hair-raising moments, its overall emotional impact is profound and surprisingly uplifting. It challenges players to confront their fears and persist through adversity, offering a silent yet powerful testament to the resilience of the human spirit.

Playdead's LIMBO is not merely a game; it is a rich, immersive experience that stimulates the senses, challenges the mind, and touches the heart. It's a hauntingly beautiful journey through the shadows, and a testament to the art of video game creation. In its quiet, understated way, LIMBO illuminates the potential of the gaming medium to tell deeply compelling, emotionally resonant stories. It's an absolute must-play for anyone who cherishes the opportunity to embark on a unique, thought-provoking adventure. I couldn't recommend it more highly.

Simply put, LIMBO is a transcendent triumph that leaves you forever changed. It lingers in your consciousness long after the credits roll, a spectral reminder of your journey through the light and darkness of the human condition.

143172871.review:
I remember liking this back in 2010 but couldn’t for the life of me remember why I never finished it. Well, doing a full playthrough now brought it all back.

As a puzzle platformer, for the most part Limbo follows the tropes of the genre in terms of gameplay. Follow the path to the right and solve any obstacles coming your way. Where Limbo differs is how it dabbles in trial-and-error gameplay and constantly tries to “get” the player. It never tells or indicates what the traps are or how to avoid them and it’s not consistent with its own rules; Big dangerous button on the ground? Sorry you were supposed to jump on it. Second button on the ground? Sorry you were supposed to jump over it. It’s just a waste of time. Many times the game also relies on janky physics to solve some of the puzzles where you have to predict how the physics will work in-game; It turns out to be the puzzle equivalent of climbing mountains in the Elder Scrolls games.

I wasn’t blown away or entertained by what the game did. For the most part it was just annoying. As was the pretentious nothing of a story that had no connection at all to the environments the game threw my way. It’s like a poorly put together map from Little Big Planet where someone wrote a paragraph for context at the start of the game. Sorry but it’s not good enough. If the game completely lacks story and is severely lacking in terms of gameplay or narrative, there really isn’t much to recommend here. 

As for the port; It’s terrible. While the game runs well and has decent controls the only way to adjust video settings is in the game files so unless you go digging there you’ll have to play it in a grainy 720p mess. Granted there isn't really much to look at here anyway so it's not that big of a deal.

143154485.review:
As much as I loved Inside, I didn't like Limbo. The game is much more difficult and relies mainly on its hair-raising puzzles, whereas Inside was visually stunning and was more intriguing, making us want to keep going. 

Inside pushed us to carry out a sequence of actions without getting too bogged down, searching in places, whereas Limbo expects us to link up actions according to a certain timing and logic. In short, it's impossible to play it calmly; you have to be quick on your feet, whereas Inside was more sedate.

I didn't like this game. Although its style is unique and creepy, the scenery doesn't have the same flavour as Inside, and I must admit that I wasn't expecting to find myself playing a puzzle game, as I have a tendency to lose patience quickly.

This is the worst game i have ever played. I dont even know where to begin. There are parts where the game just kills you for pretty much no reason and you can´t prevent it since you don´t know it is about to happen. As a result quite a few things will take you a multiple tries just because the game has a shitty design that revolves around dying in order to find the right way to solve a problem. That with the combination of when you die it takes the game multiple seconds to respawn you makes for some frustrating experience, because you are like sitting there just watching your dead body or death animation like an idiot. 
At the beginning of the game there is a giant spider chasing you and i fucking hate spiders (sad part is, that was the most interesting part of the game even for me), after that it pretty much just turns into a series of idiotic puzzles often just based on timing or shitty interactions with environment. In some puzzles the game makes you go back because there is something you need which seemed just weird to me. To be honest the last quarter of the game i just looked up how to solve the puzzles, because i was so fucking fed up with how stupid this game is i just couldn´t be bothered to try solving them for my self since solving them wasn´t even fun most of the time (and i like solving puzzles)
The game´s controls are simplistic yet idiotic at the same time. Quite a few times the game revolves around jumping at the right moment but sometimes it seems as if there is like a half second imput lag, like what is this? reminded me of the OG prince of persia (a game that is more than 30 years old btw) if you know you know
Not to mention the story is pretty much non existent. If you were to ask me what this game is about i genually have no fucking clue. The game is also short af. Most will be done with this torture around 3 hours.
The game graphics are fine if you ask me, but it does seem like the devs didn´t even want to put the work in so they just left it black and white.

I dont even remember buying this game, i think I might have claimed it during a time when it was for free and that is the only reasonable price for this game according to my personal opinion, since for playing dogshit games like this the devs should be paying you.

142540804.review:
I was so hyped before I play Limbo but as soon as I started to play I realized that this game is just another overrated indie only because its art style.

Firstly, Limbo hasn't got a story, it just has a few scenes to act like it is telling a story but they doesn't make any sense together. Especially the ending was just a meaningless 10 second scene. So it becomes impossible to make a connection with the game.

Secondly, controls are so annoying and it makes you crazy. The character doesn't jump as I wanted or he doesn't hold as I wish. It feels like I'm not controlling him, the character does whatever he wants.

Despite all this you can get entertained by Limbo's brilliantly designed puzzles. They can be really creative and difficult to solve. But one bad thing about the puzzles is they can be really cryptic and that's not good for me. Sometimes it becomes extremely challenging and i believe that %95 of the people can't finish this game without looking to a guide or walk-through video. Especially the secret level was that close to make me rage-quit.

The soundtracks are also very bad chosen and there are music only in the 10 second "storytelling" cutscenes.

Overall
Pros:
Entertaining puzzles
Good art style
Sometimes fun gameplay

Cons:
No story
No soundtracks
Bad controls
Some over difficult puzzles

Only buy it if you are a real big puzzle fan

142337925.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
You play as a boy trying to find his sister through the Limbo, a dark and mysterious world full of all kinds of mortal hazards. The game doesn't really have any dialogue, so much of the lore is up to your interpretation.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game has a very simple platforming mechanic, you just walk around and jump, there are also stairs and ropes you can climb, there are some special sections where your movements will be limited, and you will have to solve a puzzle to get back to normal. The puzzles are basically pushing/pulling objects or activating buttons at the right time. Almost every section will be full of things that can kill you, so you have to always proceed with caution.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game features 2D black and white graphics, the protagonist and platforms have a simple design while the backgrounds are more detailed, which adds some surreality to the already dark environment.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
There's practically no music in the game, just environment and atmospheric sounds, giving the game a depressive vibe, which fits well with the dark and mysterious scenarios. The sound effects are kinda loud compared to the rest of the game, but not enough to be a problem.

[h1]Price[/h1]
While the game is really well done, it's very short and it's already a bit old, so I think it should be a little cheaper than it is, so I suggest buying it when it's on sale.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
The platforming and puzzles aren't particularly hard (some of them require timing, but nothing unfair). However, there's a lot of trial and error, so you may die a bunch of times before finding a way to solve some of them, fortunately, there's also lots of checkpoints.

[h1]Duration[/h1]
The game is very short, revisiting chapters and replaying it to get the achievements may extend your playtime a bit, but it will still be kinda short.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
You'll have to play the game again to get the 'No Point in Dying" achievement, there's also a secret level that's unlocked after finishing the game for the first time and finding all hidden eggs, which will let you skip a bunch of chapters passing through a dark tunnel with some sound puzzles, this tunnel also leads you to the 'DING!' achievement.

[h1]Achievements[/h1]
Most achievements are quite easy to get, you just have to step on the hidden eggs. 'DING!' and 'No Point in Dying' are a little more complicated and may take a few tries, but are still doable.

[h1]Problems[/h1]
Some boxes in early game have a glitch where they may hurl you away, but that rarely happens and does not kill you.

142006319.review:
The negatives outweigh the positives!
The Story is so vague with it being hard to tell if there is one at all. The only objective you have is given to you on the steam page. Without it, it's a complete mystery and not in a good way. There aren't really characters and the boy you play as doesn't really have any expressions or anything to indicate emotion. I've play Playdeads other game Inside and while it might have some more clearer imagery to indicate some story, i don't get how people love the "story". Don't get me wrong i love narratives that are vague and leave the interpretation to the consumer, but there needs to be at least something for player to interpret. While the ending might be the closest thing to a plot point, the game just feels empty and out of place for the majority of the runtime. 
The Settings are fine as they're pretty typical for the platforming/puzzle genre. 
Visually I will say that it is quite unique. Performance was solid throughout my playtime and there were no signs of bugs or glitches. The Art Direction is definitely a highlight as the noir colours and silhouette design gives the game feel unsettling and tense. I also like the film/grain effect giving more character to the game. 
Sound and Audio are also pretty good with the soundtrack adding to the tension and the audio for the different items other things around the world feels fitting. 
In terms of gameplay, it got old pretty quick. The movement for the character feels right for this game as the boy with every action he takes feeling swingy and each jump that you take to climb an edge feeling really intense. The puzzles are just boring and where not satisfying to complete. There wasn't really any enemies in the game except for the spider at the start which i really enjoyed as it added a horror element to the game and was fun to try and avoid. However, the spider felt like the only threat in the game which was a real let down as i really enjoyed the spider section. Even though this game is an hour, it felt like it was dragging on for too long. While it did introduce new mechanics like flipped gravity, it didn't change it up enough resulting in the final experience feeling pretty stale at the end. 
Overall, Limbo was a disappointment as i heard some great things from it. It could be that I'm just not into games by playdead, but looking into each component individually, it just doesn't add up to be a fun time.

141763912.review:
The aesthetic is interesting but it seems like they expected that to carry the whole game. 

The puzzles flip flop between being pointlessly simple or being in one way or another impossible to solve without dying multiple times to even discover all the parts of the puzzle. Many parts of puzzles are just completely obfuscated by the dark aesthetic and in some cases it specifically teaches you to cross an obstacle one way and then immediately punishes you for learning. It's like a troll game where it seems like the creator is just trying to kill / punish you for not knowing the answers before it even reveals the parts of the puzzle to you. It just seemed kinda lame. It kills you unfairly so much that it becomes meaningless and dying stops being a deterrent... you just end up throwing yourself forward into obstacles so you can get the dying over with and learn whatever secret knowledge it's keeping from you so you can progress.

Perhaps some people like that, and perhaps I would've been able to overlook it if there was anything else in this game to latch onto. There is no story, there's no development, there's no motivation provided to even keep playing beyond morbid curiosity. The end is nothing, it's not even the hint of something, it's the most meaningless archetypal "imagine I made a good ending" fake ending I've seen in a game that isn't panned. 

The platforming is fine... it does what it can with the limited controls made available.

I'm not sure why this game is so recommended and well reviewed. It's mid as mid can get. It's not terrible, I guess. I've played worse. It's worth the 99 cents it's on sale for right now but that's about it. You probably have better games to play. It's short. It's annoying. Most of the "puzzles" don't require intelligence, the require perseverance and patience to die over and over to unfair obstacles that you could't possibly know ahead of time. I will be moving on and quickly completely forgetting this game as it is unmemorable and the memories I currently have are of being annoyed.

141708965.review:
it's [i]fiiiiiiiiiiiiiiine[/i] for what it is.
It's a short indie platformer (short as in like 2-3 hours at the very most for your first playthrough, easily under an hour if you know what you're doing already and manage to avoid the cheaper traps) with a striking silhouetted artstyle and a really neat creepy atmosphere that doesn't really have much in the way of a DELIBERATE story and instead chooses to be as vague as possible.
You don't really get a full-on "conclusion" by the end of it, just bits and pieces for you to try and figure out what you just spent the last couple hours doing.


It's REALLY short, and the only other thing you get in the way of content are some extra collectibles for achievements (which were actually pretty fun once you got a guide because FUCK some of these are cryptic), and, uh...
...a really bad really terrible really awful 'chievo for beating the whole game with less than 5 deaths.
Which isn't that good of an idea in a janky physics-based platformer that loves to throw trial and error traps at you and where the controls will occasionally screw up being physics-based as they are leading to a cheap death.
Like I was genuinely going to try and go for it and then got all 5 deaths in a row like two thirds in from one really cheap part and instantly gave up on it at that point.


At least it goes for 90% off often, it's definitely worth it like that, it's just... there isn't much here to speak of outside of the novelty of its artstyle and mood on a first run.
[b]It's alright on sale™[/b]

141100446.review: This is a dark and disturbing game and the player controls a character who moves through a nighmarish landscape and must solve difficult puzzles to progress the game. The puzzles and platforming are much harder than Inside and I had to look into walkthroughs to understand how to solve some of the puzzles when I was stuck for a long time. The game uses visual and environmental storytelling to convey its story and no language is involved. The game's story is therefore open to interpretation and the players will be left wondering who the main character they are controlling is, why is he going through this nighmarish landscape, what is the main character's purpose in the game, and where is the main character located in. Is the main character having a nightmare or is he trying to look for something or someone whom he can never get? What are those parasites in the game? Who and why are other characters in the game trying to kill the main character? What is the spider in the game? Who is the other female character in the game whom the main character meets at the end of the game but never gets to interact with her to understand who she is? The game provokes more questions than answers.

140171816.review:
El juego es increíble. No usa ni una sola palabra, y sin embargo la comunidad ha creado muchas teorías fantásticas para la historia de este juego. A pesar de que los controles son algo toscos a veces, la jugabilidad es sencilla y agradable. La ambientación y diseños visuales y sonoros son espectaculares y le vienen como anillo al dedo. Los niveles son variados, interesantes y muy originales en su diseños y mecánicas. 

Solo quisiera mencionar tres aspectos que, a mi parecer, hacen el juego un poco menos disfrutable. El primero es siento que Limbo es particularmente largo. Quizá demasiado para un juego que no usa palabras ni tiene una historia clara. He visto videoguías completas que van desde cuarenta minutos hasta poco más de una hora, y secciones como las de la persecución de la araña o toda la parte que involucra agua hacen que el juego, a veces, se sienta bastante tedioso y aburrido, ya que implica esperar mucho tiempo.

Dos. A veces, las mecánicas son algo injustas. Más allá de morir de maneras tontas porque se necesitaba un salto largo y el protagonista hace un salto muy corto, hay cosas que de verdad no me gustan. Los últimos niveles suben bastante la dificultad del juego, añadiendo timings muy precisos que, de fallarlos, te cuestan la vida. La manera en la que los controles cambian si estás en el techo o en una pared puede agarrar muy desprevenidos a algunos jugadores. A veces te sueltas de las cuerdas de la absoluta nada. A veces parece que vas a llegar en el salto y te quedas demasiado corto. Pero lo más injusto que me ha llegado a pasar es lo siguiente. 

Sin ponerme demasiado realista, intentando hacer 'speedrun' para sacar un logro he saltado o me he dejado caer desde ciertas alturas para ahorrar algunos segundos. Me choca muchísimo que, en algunos puntos o incluso secciones el niño caiga desde grandes alturas sin que le pase nada, pero en un buen intento de poco más de media hora caí desde una altura similar y morí de la absoluta nada.

Y bueno, hablando de realismo... Dadas las características del juego, el realismo no es TAN importante, pero me genera algo de tirria que el chico sea capaz de agarrarse de sogas o bordes (incluso en plena caída), tenga la fuerza suficiente para trepar cuerdas o muros (o, lo que es lo mismo, la fuerza suficiente para levantar dos veces el peso de su propio cuerpo), sea capaz de dar saltos de entre tres y cuatro metros de largo aproximadamente y, en un todo, parezca que tiene entrenamiento de gimnasia (se los digo por experiencia: hacer esas cosas es difícil y se requiere mucha fuerza y entrenamiento), pero luego no sea capaz de nadar o, al menos, de aguantar diez segundos la respiración por debajo del agua.

Tercero y último: no me termina de gustar que uno de los logros sea pasarse el juego con un máximo de cinco muertes y en una sola sesión. Lo de las muertes no es lo que me molesta. Al contrario, no me parecería mal que el juego te pidiera que lo completaras sin morir, pero sí me fastidia que deba ser en una sola sesión de juego. Prácticamente te están obligando a durar alrededor de una hora clavado frente al computador y, si pierdes, a empezar todo otra vez, lo cual es tedioso teniendo en cuenta secciones como las de la araña o la del agua. Tuve un buen intento en el que morí una sexta vez justo en la parte final, y todo porque llevaba bien el juego hasta ese momento, pero algunas mecánicas injustas se metieron en zonas complicadas y, al final, un buen intento quedó arruinado y me frustró bastante.

No son fallos graves que te arruinen la experiencia ni nada de eso. Son cosas menores que molestan por en medio. 

Por todo lo demás, Limbo es un verdadero juegazo de plataformeo y puzzles, que vale completamente la pena jugar. ¿Y el precio? Bueno, si estuviera al doble de lo que cuesta realmente, pagaría sin dudarlo. Definitivamente lo recomiendo.

140045152.review:
[h2]Once upon a time: an effort for nothing![/h2]

The boy is unconscious on the ground. He slowly opens his eyes with great pain. He gets up and finds himself in a big forest. A forest that a boy so small is afraid of. But the boy overcomes fear. Because he has to find his sister…

[h2]Black, white, thousands of colors![/h2]

Nothing can be said in praise of the graphics of this wonderful game. The creators of this game have created thousands of colors and images using white and black. The player in all places of the game praises the stunning graphics and the high accuracy of the creators in the design of the environment and objects. In fact, the environment is painted with thousands of shadows and lights, and this has caused a great increase in the beauty of the artistic graphics of this game. In fact, the creators have done a great job and have used thousands of different black and white colors. So that you feel that the whole environment of the game is painted and each color is different from the other. The design of objects in the game is also really wonderful. So that you are surprised by all this precision. From making gears and light bulbs to making a giant spider. An important point has been observed in all of these, that is, quality and accuracy! So I tell you that you will not feel any shortage in the graphics of this game. But in some places the graphics could be stronger.

[h2]Silence is the greatest music[/h2]

The sounding of this title has been done in a very precise manner and in accordance with the principles. Before dealing with the music of the game, it is necessary to mention the sounds of the objects, movement and various events of the game. From the foot of the spider sinking into the boy's body to the sound of him running on the ground, it is set so precisely that it makes the environment and atmosphere of the game more believable for the player. The sound of the rustling of the wind and the falling and rolling of a stone on the mountain is no different from the real sound of this happening in life and in the real world. It's as if the creators have made a giant spider for sound and stuck its sharp leg in a boy's body and recorded this sound and put it on their game

[h2]And the soundtrack:[/h2]

In this sector as well, Playdead has been quite successful. It is true that in many scenes silence is the only music of the game, but... but it must be admitted that this silence in the game is wonderful. Silence, next to which real sounds can be heard from the environment of a terrible forest. The silence that multiplies stress and fear in the game. A silence that should really be praised. Of course, the game in its special and emotional parts also has music that is completely in harmony with the events and makes the story more interesting.

[h2]Alone in the forest[/h2]

One of the most important parts of a game is its gameplay. No matter how great the music, graphics and story of the game are, if the gameplay of that game does not complete the rest, we will definitely face a weak title. But it must be said that this title has not left anything short for the players in this section as well.

What do you expect from the gameplay of a platformer title? If in your opinion, the great gameplay of a platformer title should be full of puzzles and different tasks, and you are supposed to face the biggest enemies in the game with simple methods and experience all kinds of vehicles in a very simple but beautiful game, and in general Never get tired of playing that title, I have to tell you that Limbo has a great gameplay.

In this game, there are no options on the game screen. In fact, you and the up, down, left and right buttons and a button to interact with the environment! There is no amount of life or... in the game, and as it was said, the game environment is completely free of any pictures or signs or writings. It is as if you are sitting in front of an animation screen. In the game you have only 2 modes, alive or dead. There is no middle ground. One mistake will kill you, and doing a simple task correctly will keep you alive, and it is not the case that, for example, your energy or life will decrease and you will be fine again! The game is completely real! Anything can cause death and death is really simple and real!

[h2]An effort for nothing[/h2]

We talked about all the parts of the game, but now we come to the biggest story of this game: its wonderful story. A story whose many parts are dumb for you. In fact, you and your belief must complete those parts of the game and complete the story. Limbo is made in such a way that everyone can make their own interpretation of it. But all perceptions are actually summed up in one concept. Something that only the player will understand after completing all the stages of the game.

Limbo literally means purgatory. The limbo in which this boy is caught. It's a terrible place for anyone…
The player is drowning in thoughts and questions. But the child overcomes the most difficult places. The boy tries his best. Finally, he uses magnetism. He does something difficult and the boy breaks the glass and is thrown in that direction. The boy is unconscious on the ground. Just like the first game...

Does the player get scared that I have been around myself all this time? What is going to happen to this little boy? The boy opens his eyes again in the same shot as the beginning of the game. He is in pain. He gets up and moves forward. It reaches the same tree house at the beginning of the game. The boy sees his sister crying over her dead body. Does this mean that this was a boy's torment? For what mistake is he tormented? This child who has not done anything to want to suffer in Purgatory. Did I mean something else? But the final message is clear:

The boy has been dead for a long time.
But there are still thousands of questions left in the mind. This game has literally destroyed the player in the story. Of course, the most painful message of the game is determined after the list of creators goes up and the game menu reappears.

Both the boy and his sister were dead.
Maybe many have not noticed this message, but if you look carefully, you will see flies flying above the 2 corpses under the tree house...

[h2]Here, several thoughts arise for the player, the best and most complete of which were as follows:[/h2]

[h2]First:[/h2] The boy and his sister go to a tree house in a forest for fun or escape. The boy's sister goes out of the hut for some reason or for example to fetch something. The boy wants to follow him, but suddenly he falls on the ground and dies. The soul of the boy who knows nothing wants to find his sister. But the forest that the player and the boy see is no longer a happy and fun forest. Rather, it is a scary and purgatory environment. A limbo that is never clear why an oppressed boy should face it! When the boy's soul wanders and passes through purgatory, the girl returns to the hut and sees her brother's dead body. The girl cries so much that she dies next to the boy...

[h2]Second:[/h2] The second theory is exactly like the above theory, except that it says that the boy and his sister both fell together and died. The boy was looking for his sister and the sister was looking for her brother. Both of them have been tasting its good torment. The girl's soul finds her brother's body and cries over his body thinking that she is alive. While both of them were dead.

The second theory is more likely to be true due to the evidence. Because at the end of the game, the girl sees the boy and gets up and runs away. How could he see a ghost if he wasn't dead? In addition, in the middle of the game, a girl can be seen wandering in the forest in several places. Just like his brother.

But all this is of no importance. Your opinion of this wonderful story is important. A story that many of us still don't understand...
A game that you have to think about after finishing it...
To the boy and his sister.

140034559.review:
I am a 45 years old father with a teenage son who loves playing video games. I have always struggled to connect with my son as he spends most of his free time playing games online or watching others play on YouTube. As a busy single father, I found it difficult to spend quality time with him.

But recently, my son introduced me to a game called Limbo, and I decided to create a Steam account so we could play together. It had been decades since I last played a video game, so I was quite rusty. But my son patiently taught me how to play and we started bonding over this game.

I was pleasantly surprised by how much fun we had playing together. It was like we were solving a mystery together, laughing and having a great time. Playing video games with my son reminded me of the joy of being a kid and it helped me to connect with my son on a whole new level. We even started spending more time together outside of the game, going on walks and enjoying other activities.

As a single father, it can be difficult to find common ground with my son, but video games have given us a new way to bond and spend quality time together. I am grateful for this opportunity to connect with my son and make lasting memories together.

139826806.review:
LIMBO is a mesmerizing and atmospheric puzzle-platformer that takes players on a haunting journey through a mysterious and treacherous world. Developed by Playdead, this indie game captivates with its minimalist visuals, eerie ambiance, and thought-provoking puzzles, creating an unforgettable experience that lingers in the mind long after the game is over.

One of the standout features of LIMBO is its unique art style. The game employs a monochromatic palette and silhouetted characters, creating a stark and atmospheric world that is both beautiful and unsettling. The minimalistic graphics work in perfect harmony with the game's haunting sound design to build a sense of suspense and tension, drawing players deeper into the enigmatic narrative.

The gameplay in LIMBO revolves around solving puzzles and overcoming environmental obstacles, all while navigating through a dark and perilous landscape. The puzzles are ingeniously designed, often requiring players to think outside the box and experiment with the environment to progress. The lack of hand-holding and explicit instructions adds to the game's allure, allowing players to discover and unravel its secrets at their own pace.

One of the game's strengths is its ability to create a sense of fear and unease without relying on jump scares or explicit violence. The foreboding atmosphere and the lurking dangers keep players on edge throughout their journey, making every step forward a nerve-wracking experience. LIMBO expertly balances suspense and intrigue, delivering an immersive and emotional narrative that resonates with players on a deep level.

The relatively short length of LIMBO may be seen as a drawback for some, but it is precisely this brevity that allows the game to maintain its captivating momentum. Each puzzle and encounter feels purposeful, and the concise storytelling keeps players engaged from start to finish. It's a concentrated dose of atmospheric brilliance that leaves a lasting impact.

In conclusion, LIMBO is a masterclass in atmospheric storytelling and puzzle design. Its striking visuals, eerie ambiance, and intelligent puzzles create a mesmerizing and unforgettable experience. If you're looking for a thought-provoking and haunting adventure that challenges both your intellect and emotions, LIMBO is an absolute must-play. Step into the shadows and embrace the enigma that awaits in this indie gem.

If you like the review and it encourage you to buy this game, I will be very happy if you give it an Award. Thanks!

[b] Ukrainian: [/b]
[u] "Limbo" [/u] - це потрясаюче красива і атмосферна гра,яка поглинає гравців у темний та загадковий світ.Від моменту початку гри ви потрапляєте в монохромний пейзаж, наповнений жахливими силуетами та фоновими звуками,що створюють відчуття незручності та напруги.

Одна з найбільш помітних особливостей гри "Limbo" - це її унікальний стиль мистецтва.Візуальне оформлення гри виконано в чорно-білих тонах з виразними контрастами та мінімалістичними деталями,що сприяють загальному відчуттю зловіщості.Використання світла та тіней майстерно виконане,додаючи глибину та жахливу атмосферу кожній сцені.

Геймплей в "Limbo" зосереджений на розв'язанні середовищних головоломок та подоланні різних перешкод.Головоломки вигадливо сконструйовані,вимагаючи від гравців виходу за рамки звичайних рішень і експериментів з різними підходами. Відсутність навчальних посібників або явних інструкцій додає відчуття відкриття і заохочує гравців до дослідження та вивчення шляхом проб і помилок.

Те,що відрізняє "Limbo",це його здатність створювати відчуття вразливості та напруги.У ролі головного героя, маленького хлопчика,ви маневруєте небезпечними оточуючими середовищами та зустрічаєтеся з смертельними пастками і страхітливими створіннями.Нещадливість гри додає постійної небезпеки,підсилюючи напруження і роблячи кожен успіх відчутним.

Хоча "Limbo" - це виняткова гра,варто зауважити,що вона може не підходити кожному.Темні і затишні теми, разом з викликом головоломок,можуть бути інтенсивними і не приваблювати гравців,які шукають більш легковажного досвіду. Крім того,сюжет залишається підкресленим для інтерпретації,що деякі гравці можуть вважати сумнівним або неситисфакційним.

Заключно, "Limbo" - це вражаюча та атмосферна гра,яка пропонує унікальний та захоплюючий досвід.Її виразний візуальний стиль,захоплюючі головоломки та жахлива атмосфера роблять її видатною грою в інді-геймінгу.Якщо вам подобаються атмосферні,захоплюючі ігри з темним відтінком,"Limbo" варто спробувати.

139429890.review:
LIMBO is a 2D platformer with some puzzle and some horror elements. I've heard this game be described as a horror game, and while there are a few moments that might shock you or motivate you to run, it's not the primary focus of the game to terrify the player.
Although it's not mentioned in-game, the point of the game is for the protagonist, the boy, to find his sister. In his pursuit, you will have to navigate a lot of dangerous environments and enemies.
It seems like this game takes place within the same universe as INSIDE, the spiritual successor to LIMBO. Even though it doesn't seem that they share the same location, you can draw parallels between parts of each game (for example, a transition from a natural to an industrial setting, and calming music playing during very stressful and intense timed puzzles). However, LIMBO is much, much less graphic and body-horror focused than INSIDE, so if you are looking to try Playdead games, I would start here.
Most of the puzzles are intuitively explained, but there are a few that feel a little poorly designed. I had to look up a guide for a puzzle involving a pulley relatively early on in the game, and the solution was something I didn't even think was doable. INSIDE improves on this mostly, though.
As far as the story goes: Nearly all storytelling is done environmentally, so pay attention to the environment and use that to speculate on the ending and the world as a whole. I don't think there is a "correct" answer here.
It's a good game with a couple puzzles you might get stuck on for a bit, but beautiful in the playdead-trademarked grim way otherwise.

The game is pretty dark...
Some level designs are very fluid...

Puns aside, the game is very short (roughly an hour) and linear. Not much coherent lore/plot either.
Controls are pretty simple and tight; leaving little room for random shenanigans but they can occur when climbing objects for example. Luckily there's no overrated speedrun achievement and the no_death challenge is rather lenient. Secrets and puzzles in general can be figured out with the clues given, but then again a couple of them leave the player very dumbfounded the first time and may need outside sourcing.

The biggest gripes I have with the game is that there are waiting scenes that cannot be bypassed; worsened if one would for some unthinkable reason have to replay the game.

The most impressive feat of the game is that albeit very peculiar, the levels inside the same playthrough are very unique and obstacles are not as repetitive and blending together as pretty much every other platformer out there. ALSO notable are a couple... common platformer elements? and door mechanics that I've seen in more popular games like Ori and the blind forest years later, so I suppose this title inspired later titles.
