138472277.review:
Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Limbo is an exquisite masterpiece that flawlessly combines atmospheric storytelling, minimalist aesthetics, and ingenious puzzle-solving to create an unforgettable gaming experience. Developed by Playdead, this indie gem casts players into a hauntingly beautiful monochromatic world where danger lurks at every turn.

From the moment you step into Limbo's grim and foreboding environment, you're immediately captivated by its eerie atmosphere. The game's grayscale visuals, accompanied by moody lighting and subtle animations, create an ambiance that is both enchanting and disquieting. The absence of colors allows the game's meticulously crafted environments and intricate level design to shine, immersing you in a world that feels ethereal yet disturbingly real.

Limbo's narrative is entirely wordless, relying solely on visual cues and environmental storytelling to convey its enigmatic tale. As you guide the young protagonist through a macabre landscape filled with perilous traps and enigmatic creatures, you gradually unravel the mystery behind his journey. The story's enigmatic nature leaves much open to interpretation, inviting players to speculate and contemplate its deeper meaning, which adds a layer of intellectual engagement to the experience.

The true brilliance of Limbo lies in its puzzles, which are ingeniously designed to challenge your wits and intuition. Each obstacle presents a unique and often deadly dilemma that requires careful observation and experimentation to overcome. The game's physics-based puzzles are refreshingly inventive, requiring you to manipulate objects, time movements precisely, and think outside the box to progress. Every triumph over an obstacle feels immensely rewarding, and the sense of satisfaction it elicits is unparalleled.

The attention to detail in Limbo is simply astonishing. The atmospheric sound design, composed of subtle ambient sounds and eerie melodies, heightens the tension and adds another layer of immersion to the gameplay. Combined with the meticulous animation and seamless controls, the game feels incredibly polished and refined, offering a smooth and intuitive experience from start to finish.

Despite its dark and gloomy tone, Limbo manages to evoke a sense of beauty and wonderment through its artistry and creativity. It is a testament to the fact that games can be emotionally evocative and thought-provoking without relying on excessive dialogue or flashy graphics.

Limbo is a breathtaking journey that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. Its combination of artistic prowess, atmospheric brilliance, and ingenious puzzles makes it an unforgettable experience that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll. If you're a fan of immersive storytelling and enjoy intellectual challenges, Limbo is an absolute must-play, an exceptional masterpiece that showcases the true potential of indie gaming.

138456902.review: Much as I would recommend to at the very least take a *look* at this game for its beautiful aesthetics, I have words on its gameplay and puzzle elements. The controls are easy and straightforward; the movement associated with those is fine enough. Unfortunately, the animations slow down the response time, creating a slight input lag of a sort. In a game not based around timing, that would be perfectly acceptable. This game hinges on it. Most timing windows are extremely narrow and failing them means death. Not only that, approaching the majority of puzzles for the first time, it is almost entirely unlikely that you will be able to predict the outcome of environment-changing actions, which are a-plenty in this game. As a result, death is *almost* a guarantee; also evident by the ultimate achievement having the allowance of 5 deaths. Yet, it is consistent, the checkpoints are generously placed, and the set pieces and the narrative are quite, quite neat.

If you buy this bundled together with INSIDE, you'll see that they learnt some lessons from Limbo and did things better in their newer game.
I am mostly talking about the game's respect towards first tries.
First tries are extremely important. In games, i want to be rewarded for observing the surroundings, identifying danger and dodging it the first time i meet it. Because if you die even once, the unknown becomes known and the victory is soured by the feeling that its less deserved, the valid feeling that i essentially cheated by scouting ahead in the previous "life".
Therefore, having to see the character die to poorly communicated hazards over and over takes away greatly from joy.
You could justify this by framing it as "difficulty" and tell me to just git gud. But i think you would be asking from the player too much, and i KNOW that it can be done better - because in INSIDE it is.
INSIDE is much more wary of the importance of first tries and also looks better.
Even though the game was well worth the money on sale, i leave a negative review to tip the scales. The masses, as is often the case, overrated this game.

137898278.review:
Limbo, developed by Playdead, is a dark and atmospheric indie puzzle-platformer that has managed to captivate me from the moment I started playing it on Ubuntu. The game's eerie aesthetics, challenging puzzles, and engaging gameplay make for an experience I won't forget any time soon (for my girlfriend was a little too hardcore but she finally enjoyed it).

Right from the start, Limbo's grayscale visuals and minimalistic sound design create a unique atmosphere that is simultaneously haunting and enchanting. The game plunges you into a world of silhouettes and shadows, with background details that are both intriguing and unsettling. The sparse use of sound and music adds to the eerie ambience, making even the quietest moments feel tense.

The story in Limbo is minimalistic, yet powerful. You play as a young boy searching for his sister in an eerie, otherworldly landscape. The game doesn't rely on exposition or dialogue; instead, it allows you to interpret the narrative based on the environment and situations you encounter. This leaves room for personal interpretation and makes the experience feel more immersive and mysterious.

Limbo's gameplay is a well-balanced blend of platforming and puzzle-solving. The game constantly introduces new mechanics and challenges that force you to think critically and adapt your approach. The puzzles range from simple physics-based conundrums to intricate, multi-layered challenges that require patience and a keen eye for detail. The game is never too easy, but it also never feels unfair, striking the perfect balance of difficulty.

Playing Limbo on Ubuntu was a smooth experience. The game runs flawlessly, and the controls are responsive and intuitive. It's clear that the developers put thought into making the game accessible to Linux users, which is much appreciated.

It's hard to find any drawbacks in Limbo. While some players might argue that the game's relatively short length is a downside, I see completing it in under six hours as a significant advantage. In an era where many games and series tend to drag on and eventually lose their charm or deliver unsatisfying endings, Limbo's concise nature is a breath of fresh air. Furthermore, for those with limited gaming time, Limbo serves as the perfect escape, offering a rich and satisfying experience without demanding an excessive time investment.

137666694.review:
Limbo is a 2D puzzle-platformer where you play as a boy trying to find his sister. You will cross forests, caves, and industrial areas to get to her. This game is fairly known for having a unique style, everything is in shadowy black and white. Despite its style, I wouldn't really call it a horror game, as it is not scary and has no scary moments whatsoever. It just has a dark atmosphere and shadow-looking characters.

Gameplay is linear, basically your objective is to go right as far as you can. But there are obstacles along the way, from simple ones such as jumping gaps, to more complex ones such as outsmarting enemies, avoiding traps, and solving puzzles. Some puzzles are physics-based, and they start out easy, but later on it gets more complicated and relies on timing and precision. There's also collectibles, in the form of glowing eggs, If you collect all of them (you can use chapter select) you'll be able to enter a secret area. It's pretty difficult, since the whole area is dark and you're unable to see anything. You'll have to rely on audio cues to predict the level.

I know it may feel like heresy, but to be honest I am not really a fan of this game. It's quite difficult (though never impossible) in some areas in the later chapters, and starts to feel like a chore. My favorite parts of the game are the ones where you fight the giant spider with traps and environmental hazards, but sadly there are not many levels like that, most of the time it just feels like one puzzle after another. The story is also almost nonexistent besides "boy must find sister" as there are no dialogues or anything. Oh and the secret area? Trial-and-error-fest, even more than the whole game.

Limbo is an important indie game, even more when you realize it's released in 2011 where stylized indie games are probably still very few. It's still a pretty unique game, just don't expect a relaxing time when playing through. Their next game Inside seems to improve upon many things, like being more story-based, colorful, and most importantly easier. But it is very cheap on sale, so it might be worth checking out if you're into platformers and can handle frustration.

137528646.review:
Limbo is a hauntingly beautiful puzzle-platformer game developed by Playdead that has captivated players since its release. The game's black-and-white art style creates a dark and eerie atmosphere that perfectly matches the game's themes of death, danger, and exploration.

The game's puzzles are challenging yet fair, requiring players to use their wits and problem-solving skills to progress through the game's levels. Each puzzle is expertly designed and offers a unique challenge that will keep players engaged and motivated.

The game's platforming mechanics are also exceptional, with precise controls and physics that make movement feel satisfying and responsive. The game's levels are cleverly designed, offering a mix of exploration, puzzles, and combat that never feels repetitive or dull.

One of the game's standout features is its narrative, which is told without any dialogue or text. Instead, players must piece together the story through the environment, the actions of the characters, and the events that unfold. The result is a deeply immersive and engaging experience that rewards careful observation and attention to detail.

The game's sound design is also exceptional, with a haunting and atmospheric score that perfectly matches the game's visuals and themes. Every sound in the game is expertly crafted to create an immersive and engaging experience that draws players into the world of Limbo.

Overall, Limbo is a masterpiece of game design that has stood the test of time. Its haunting visuals, challenging puzzles, and engaging narrative make it a game that is definitely worth playing for fans of puzzle-platformers, horror games, or anyone looking for a unique and immersive gaming experience.

137523471.review:
I know that this game is an absolute classic, but I've got to be honest with myself. I don't think I can, in good faith, recommend this to most people. the atmosphere is great, the world is intriguing and horrifying, but the game plays awful. There are sections that are extremely slow and require waiting for a pretty long time, but if you die you go straight back to the beginning of them and have to wait through the slow moment again. If you die again, guess what you have to do again: wait through the slow moment. I probably wasted a good 5 or 10 minutes in a couple chapters of this game just because I had to wait before I could do anything, and then died either because of my own incompetence or because of the floaty and hard to predict controls.

Not only that, but this game also has very little to do for options. The ingame options only allow you to change the brightness. The rest of the options aren't in the game, but in an options text file that is in the game's folder. Those options don't even allow you to change that much. The two most prominent options in there are turning off controller vibrations (more on that shortly) and changing the game to windowed mode.

For some reason, the game is also terribly optimized. Once you reach a certain point in the game (probably about half an hour in), it randomly begins to drop frames to as low as like 5 fps, and thats on my PC with a 3070 TI. The way to fix it? turning off controller vibration. How do you make a game where controller vibration affects the graphical output of the game. 

Basically, the game is clunky, aggravating, and not user friendly. If you can pick it up cheap (like the $0.99 that it's on sale for at the time of writing the review), it's probably worth it to play a classic game. Otherwise I'd say this game is probably a pass.

137398411.review:
A rough platformer with no sense of flow.

Confusingly the game throws you into the start, which is slow, and has no hints, and the settings are terrible. The visuals are smushed, as if the resolution is low, and I found no video options to change it. The contrast of raw white and black was jarring even when I wasn't playing at night. Left-CTRL is used to grab objects, but this isn't explained. If you touch water you die, yet you can sometimes throw yourself off the map and survive.

Limbo often plays like a 2D physics game, but the puzzle solutions are either basic or make no sense, which is surprising because the lack of video settings as a platformer makes it feel like one of those platformer shovelware games. I'd say it was surprising in a bad way, as the design feels incoherent, where the focus should have been on making the gameplay flow - if you can drag things that are probably too heavy to be dragged or would snap your hands off, then why can't you climb a few feet or stand in shallow water?

The theme is edgy, and a lot of the puzzles are totally nonsensical. Why couldn't they add some hint of intuition? How are you supposed to feel immersed if you keep tabbing out to check a walkthrough? I feel like platformers should be engaging, not confusing. Is this worth £8.99? I don't think so. Why would I recommend a game to friends if I had to relay the hints for the most basic things like controls when the game should do it itself? What's wrong with making a product user-friendly?

137245599.review:
LIMBO is a puzzle-platformer game that has captured the hearts of many gamers with its unique and minimalist approach to storytelling. The game's grayscale visuals and hauntingly beautiful soundtrack create an eerie and immersive atmosphere that draws the player in and keeps them engaged throughout the game.

The game's puzzles are well-designed and offer just the right amount of challenge to keep the player engaged without feeling frustrated. The game's mechanics are intuitive and responsive, which allows for a smooth and enjoyable gaming experience. The game's physics-based puzzles are particularly impressive, and the way they interact with the environment adds another layer of depth to the game.

The game's story is told without any dialogue, leaving it up to the player to interpret the game's meaning and symbolism. This approach to storytelling is unique and refreshing, and it adds another layer of mystery to the game. The game's ending is particularly memorable and offers a satisfying conclusion to the player's journey.

Overall, LIMBO is a beautifully crafted game that offers a unique and immersive experience for players. Its minimalist approach to storytelling, well-designed puzzles, intuitive mechanics, and hauntingly beautiful visuals and soundtrack make it a must-play for anyone who enjoys puzzle-platformer games.

136700291.review:
Well, well, well, look who's a Limbo master with all the achievements. Congratulations! Now, let's talk about this hauntingly beautiful game.

First of all, can we talk about the art style? It's like Tim Burton and Salvador Dali had a baby and it grew up to make video games. The black and white aesthetic is simple yet stunning, and the use of lighting and shadows is nothing short of masterful.

But let's get to the real heart of the game: the puzzles. Limbo is like a Rubik's Cube that wants to kill you. Every level presents a new challenge, and just when you think you've got it figured out, the game throws a curveball at you. And let's not forget about the traps. If you're not careful, you'll end up impaled on spikes, sliced in half by a saw, or drowned in a pool of water. Fun times.

But despite all the challenges, the feeling of satisfaction when you finally solve a puzzle is unbeatable. It's like you're a genius, even though you probably just got lucky. And with all the achievements under your belt, you can finally say that you've truly conquered Limbo.

Overall, Limbo is a stunning and challenging game that will keep you on your toes...or on your back, bleeding out. If you're a fan of puzzle games, artistic masterpieces, and the occasional death trap, then this game is a must-play. Just make sure you have a lot of patience and a high tolerance for frustration, because you're gonna need both.

My first time playing Limbo was back when it came out in 2011. It was probably my first ever Indie Game and it woke my interest for "smaller" Games. You can clearly see that Limbo inspired a lot of Games that came afterwards - Little Nightmares, for example.

136617388.review:
The game delves into sensitive topics like suicide and arachnophobia, which may not be suitable for all players. However, for those who dare to play, they will discover a visually stunning game with a simple yet captivating storyline.

The player takes on the role of a protagonist who wakes up in a forest and embarks on a quest to find their missing sister. The open ending of the game allows for interpretation, with two theories standing out.

One theory presents a religious vision of Catholic limbo, where virtuous people who have not accepted Christianity for various reasons are sent to limbo. By the time the game begins, the protagonist and his sister are already dead, and the puzzles lead them to their final meeting that will help them move into the afterlife.

The second theory suggests that the protagonist killed his sister and is now trapped in a cycle of reliving this path. Evidence supporting this theory is the staircase from the end of the game, which appears in the main menu and is rotten with two corpses at the bottom.

Solving puzzles is the main mechanic of the game, and while some puzzles may not seem logical, they are always intriguing. The game's design and atmosphere will keep players engaged for 1-2 hours, or around 6-10 hours if they aim to unlock all possible achievements.

It's important to note that the game is not recommended for those with arachnophobia or discomfort with the game's themes. However, for those seeking an immersive and thought-provoking experience, the game comes highly recommended.

Bueno tengo un par de cosas que decir a cerca del juego.

Para empezar, es un juego corto (y no lo culpo, las razones son obvias) y por eso mismo me esperaba algo "normal", un plataformero corto promedio, un juego que está hecho con ese propósito; empezarlo, jugarlo, y pasártelo sin nada sobresaliente de por medio y que te lo pasas en pocas horas, perooooo...

Para ser un juego corto debo decir que lo disfruté mucho. Hay claramente mucho que destacar como por ejemplo: La buena banda sonora acompañada de los buenos efectos de sonido, una buena ambientación, una historia aunque corta pero destacable y muy bien ambientada con lo anterior ya mencionado, y lo más sobresaliente en mi opinión; los puzzles. Si, puede que no todos seamos amantes de ellos pero, no me van a negar que la satisfacción que se siente al momento de completar un puzzle en este juego es simplemente hilarante (ustedes ya me comprenden), y es por eso mismo que de tener pensado jugarlo unas pocas horas terminé por aumentar unas cuantas más y valieron totalmente la pena. Debo decir que hace mucho que un juego no me desafiaba tanto, hace mucho que un juego no me ponía ese "enigma" a resolver o esa frustración de no poder resolver algo que en principio, parecía complejo, pero que al mucho observar caes en el engaño porque resulta que no era tan grotesco como se pensaba... 

En fin, ahora hay una única queja departe mía; sin alargarlo mucho, el juego es corto... yyy eso ya se sabía ¿cierto?.... puess, ese es el problema, me quedé corto en todo aspecto, y ya dije que no lo culparía, pero el juego tiene tanto potencial que daba para más, para mucho más; tanto en lore como en escenarios y lo más importante creo yo, se queda demasiado corto en lo que más destaca; los puzzles. Me quedé con ganas de resolver más, de saber más del lore/historia, de  conocer nuevos escenarios, etc. 

Tan solo espero que hagan una continuación ya sea como precuela o secuela, yo estaría muy agradecido con ello. Gracias por este maravilloso juego.

135656530.review:
LIMBO is game which works hard to create a great atmosphere, and lives up to the motto "show by doing" - i.e. there are no tutorials/cut scenes and leaves much to interpretation. It's a short game (4-5 hours , <1 hour if you actually know how the puzzles work) so I was able to beat it in about one session.

I can't really in good conscience recommend that game however to the average gamer, as the puzzles (which almost always start with walking into a random death) are just not satisfying to solve - especially in the latter half of the game. You may even find the right solution early, but slightly missing a jump could put you off that solution as the game doesn't provide any feedback. Once you finally get through that section, it feels like lucking into the right solution instead of the result of smart play.

The early chapters were pretty good so its not a terrible game in the least, but I felt pot-committed to finish the game in the second half. I paid $0.99 for the game, and it was well worth this price even with the overall slightly negative experience I had.

Do yourself a favor and play INSIDE instead (or again) which is made by the same studio and is a master piece if you are new to the genre. LIMBO was obviously a stepping stone for this talented group of devs, and you may still enjoy it if you REALLY liked INSIDE, but it can be skipped in my opinion (and I've played a lot of puzzle platforming games).

[h1] Suicide and spiders. [/h1]

The game is a thrilling and unsettling experience that may not be for everyone, as it deals with sensitive topics like suicide and spiders. But for those who dare to venture into its world, they will be rewarded with a visually stunning game with a simple yet captivating storyline. 

The game follows the protagonist who wakes up in a forest and embarks on a journey to find his missing sister. The open ending of the game leaves room for interpretation, and two theories stand out: 
[olist]
[*] Presents a religious vision of the Catholic limbo, where there are souls who have not gone to heaven, purgatory, or hell. Virtuous people who have not accepted Christianity for various reasons are sent to limbo. By the time the game starts, the boy and the girl are already dead and the puzzles lead the heroes to the last meeting that will help them move into the afterlife.

[*] According to the second theory, the boy killed his sister and is now forced to constantly repeat this path. Evidence of the theory is the staircase from the final of the game, which appears in the main menu, but there it is rotten and with two corpses at the bottom. [/olist]

Solving puzzles is the core mechanic of the game, and while some puzzles may not seem logical, they are always interesting. The game's atmosphere and design will keep you engaged for about 1-2 hours, or around 6-10 hours if you aim to unlock all possible achievements.

It's worth noting that the game is not suitable for those with arachnophobia or a discomfort with the game's themes. However, for those looking for an immersive and thought-provoking experience, the game is highly recommended.

But it doesn't need to be anything more than that, because the game executes the puzzles very well. The game starts off with introductory puzzles that aren't too hard and introduce the player to the game and slowly build up in difficulty over-time. It does this perfectly and it very much contributes to the enjoyment of the game, as there are very few times where you find a puzzle that just doesn't make sense (Pretty much anytime I got stuck it was because I failed to notice hints that the game was giving me.) I get the feeling that the game has some kind of story to it but if it does it really fails to communicate it but that doesn't matter as story has practically nothing to do with gameplay. Overall, a simple but enjoyable experience, 8/10.

134964680.review:
Simple and magnificent, Limbo is a very enjoyable game from start to end. Truly art in a videogame.

There is no story (more or less), but the closest thing we have is that the boy (protagonist) is in search of his sister. In this way  he proposes to cross a misterious and dark world. 

It's easy to understand how to play: arrows for movements, CTRL for actions. The game progresses with puzzles, where you need to time in most of them and use logic. Many times can be frustrating to miss an obstacle because a second.

But the cherry on the top of Limbo is the graphics and art. Despite using from white, black and tones of gray, is impressive how beautiful and misterious can the scenario be, and with the lack of colors, the game feels better. The scenario changes from a forest to a factory and the roofs of a town. Definitely Playdead made a good job with this. 

Included with the art, the soundtrack and sound effects are like a ring to the finger. There is barely music, but it makes you feel in other world. A world that you are the outlander, where you don't know if you are alone or someone is watching you... The sound effects are truly good too, feeling natural. 

The game includes 13 archiements, where 10 are related to finding eggs (collectibles), one is about finishing the game, one is related to a secret after finding the eggs and the last one is a pain in the ass: NO POINT IN DYING. Basically, completing the game dying no more than 5 times. Despite being short and with most of the puzzles being easy to memorize, many times you will rage after almost finishing the game and flopping, making it the 6th death. Oh, also includes badges.

From my point of view, it's truly overpriced. For a game from 2010, which you can finish in 1h and is too simple, I wouldn't spend the 10€ it costs. Instead, buy it on sales when it's 1€, the price that deserves.

Just like I mentioned, Limbo is a truly unique gaming experience which you can live in the first playthrough, and something every gamer should experience at least once

134898164.review:
Phenomenal Concept, but horrible execution (pun maybe intended). 
So glad I didn't pay full price for the "joy" of sticking nails through my arms and enduring interminably slow game play. I get the concept of making games difficult to be difficult, but making them SLOW for the sake of trying your patience?
The game starts out so promising, but the further I moved along, the more I found myself sneering at the "puzzles". It's not that they're overly difficult, but even once you learn the solution, you'll spend another 2 to 8 minutes having to learn how to finesse the solution into working while enduring certain elements moving at a glacial pace. Over and over and over and over in some spots. 
Or, just as bad, is KNOWING the solution, but having to figure out why the solution isn't actually working even though you know what the end goal is. Case in point--the mosquito bit. I KNEW exactly what I had "to do" to get past it, but figuring out that I was doing the right thing in slightly the wrong spot (after 6 f*cking minutes) pissed me off, because there was zero indication I needed to be doing what I was already doing, I just needed to be a hair more to the left when I did it. Failure was my ONLY indication that what seemed like a perfectly reasonable solution WAS a reasonable solution, but completely worthless unless done just a bit further from what appeared to be the right spot to do it. 
Task failed successfully.
There are numerous other bits of this type of frustration. And mixed in with the life-support speed of movement....I can't recommend it, despite how much promise it shows.

¿Qué es LIMBO? En esencia, es un juego de plataformas y puzles en 2D y en blanco y negro. Ahora bien, más allá de esa descripción superficial, LIMBO es el mejor ejemplo (que yo haya visto hasta ahora) de minimalismo en un videojuego. Es decir, de hacer más con menos, de expresar una idea con lo esencial, eliminando lo superfluo.

Por destacar algo en concreto, me quedo con el diseño de niveles. Tanto en el [i]plataformeo[/i] como en los puzles me ha parecido de diez, perfecto. Lo único negativo es su duración (da para unas 2-3 horas), pero también es fácil encontrarlo rebajado, así que no es excusa.

Muy recomendado.

134634156.review:
i played the game for times in mobile iphone ,The game Limbo can be interpreted as a metaphor for the human experience of searching for meaning and purpose in life. The protagonist of the game, a young boy searching for his missing sister, can be seen as a representation of humanity as a whole, seeking to understand its place in the world.

The dark, monochromatic setting of the game can be seen as a symbol for the existential void that many people feel when confronted with the fundamental questions of life, such as the meaning of existence and the nature of reality. The puzzles that the player must solve in order to progress through the game can be seen as representations of the obstacles and challenges that we face in our own lives as we try to find meaning and purpose.

Ultimately, the game's open-ended narrative and ambiguous ending can be seen as a reflection of the fact that there are no easy answers to the big questions of life. Instead, the game encourages us to think deeply about these questions and to come to our own conclusions about what it means to be human.

Overall, Limbo is a thought-provoking and deeply philosophical game that invites players to explore some of the most fundamental questions of human existence.

134587335.review:
[h3]Flavour[/h3]
LIMBO is a Puzzle Platformer that heavily invests in creating a certain disquieting mood through its oppressive atmosphere and visuals. It's loved because it made people succumb to it. Step by step, you get absorbed in the chirping of critters, buzzing of flies, and echoes of dripping water. The droning soundscape pertains to immersion and feels like having high blood pressure. Coated in layers of milky dead light and shadowy mist, you enter a spiralling world of dampened madness that deals in last-ditch efforts and split-second saves. There's always a sense of threat in its stuffy air, and barely any breathing room between instances when your boy becomes prey to another predatory menace. This is only appropriate, for the stakes are high - he submerged to break out his sister.

I only know it because it's written on the store page, don't expect a plot. But expect to see kids nonchalantly squashed by industrial presses. The game's world brings upon a foreboding sensation of uncaring cruelty, pitched again the boy's vulnerability, firmly tapping into the realms of morbid existential horror. Purgatory tortures you with things you don't want to see, beings you'd rather stay away from, and places you desire to be inside the least. It doesn't fancy you being there either, returning violation for violation. Although, violence is applied purposefully, transforming your mutual revulsion into the main attraction. That place doesn't hate you, doesn't want you, it doesn't think of you at all. This is one uncanny property, which makes our generally self-centred worldview shrink and tremble.

[h3]Substance[/h3]
Surprisingly, the game is mechanically sound, it's not just about going right. But it's mostly about going down the drain of doom and facing creepy, slimy, miserable abominations lurking within its premises. The boy can't swim, but he can jump, pull up, swing, climb, push, and pull. LIMBO teaches you all that without saying a word. I'd say the controls are a bit wonky, aimed at showing off smooth animations rather than immediately reacting to your presses, but it's not a big deal due to relatively slow pace and frequent autosaves. You'll need them in that cursed place where every jump is impossible, every boulder or spike misses you by a hair, every living and non-living thing is death.

In LIMBO, you'll see no reverence for the dead and nothing but disdain for life itself. Corpses to climb, corpses to solve puzzles with, corpses to use as snowboards. There's enough fun to be had without making your own, though. A few thrilling chases make way for decently varied puzzles, the crux of it all. Those are uncomplicated, yet clever and elegant. A couple of them were able to stump me for quite a while, this game isn't that easy. I've heard an opinion that it's somehow boring or tedious. How tedious can it be if barely any challenge lasts a minute? And how can it be boring if there's no downtime? Although, I understand why some may have disliked it when the setting switched from the gloomy woods to an industrial area. I also thought it was bland in comparison.

[h3]Closure[/h3]
LIMBO was out before the puzzle platformer formula was refined by Inside and Little Nightmares, hence, I didn't expect the same level of panache initially. But it struck a chord with me, then two, three, all of them at once! It didn't feel as if I was dealing with some inanimate relic like a useless old sock without a pair. I saw that this game couldn't be anything but a child of love whose soaring to fame wasn't a fluke. It holds up in the present, it will always hold up, and its past success wasn't about coming out at the right time and place. It's about every trick in its book coming from genuine artistic integrity. I firmly believe that LIMBO deserves the praise received and a place in the pantheon of semi-modern classics. Not exactly a hot take, I know.

My curator [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35305390-Big-Bad-Mutuh/?appid=262060]Big Bad Mutuh[/url]

134574432.review:
The immersive experience of the game is created by its monochromatic visuals, minimalist sound design, and eerie atmosphere. When playing, one takes control of an anonymous boy who awakens in a dark and ominous forest without any clear objectives or path to follow. As progress is made throughout the game's challenges continue to grow more difficult forcing players to solve increasingly complex puzzles while overcoming obstacles before moving forward towards uncovering answers about their haunting surroundings.

LIMBO possesses a particular talent for inducing apprehension and unease by means that do not involve jarring surprises or graphic violence. By weaving subtle suggestions and indications, the game manages to sustain interest in its narrative while also presenting cerebral quandaries whose resolution delivers deep gratification.

One remarkable feature of LIMBO is its implementation of gameplay based on trial and error. Frequently, the gamer must try new approaches and solutions to advance in the game, which occasionally leads to irritation but ultimately grants a satisfying experience.

LIMBO is an exceptional and captivating adventure that demands to be played. Its haunting ambiance, perplexing enigmas, and skillful narrative come together harmoniously to produce a genuinely memorable game encounter.

Overall, LIMBO is a unique and immersive experience that is well worth playing. Its haunting atmosphere, challenging puzzles, and subtle storytelling combine to create a truly unforgettable gaming experience.

134548202.review:
Limbo is one of those games that easily warrants a replay, not only just because it's fun; but also the puzzles are good and in the first playthrough there'll be a lot of room for trial and error (and death).

Some of the [i]best[/i] things about this game: the atmosphere and gritty noir art style; the eerie and top notch sound design; the puzzles and enigmatic situations that you get trapped in. 

Another thing I loved was the ambiguity in the story, you don't know for certain where it's going and how it's going to be end, but when it does it will leave you speechless even though we don't invest much in the character(s). It's open to interpretation which is very fitting for the game in my opinion.

Easily a 10/10. I so much want to try more games like this. Gonna start with [b]Inside[/b] which is by the same developers!

134012996.review: This little platformer has a beautifully dark and gloomy art style, creepy ambient sound and effects, and it’s littered with surprising and gruesome traps. Enough so to give me a few jump-scares, especially in the beginning. It’s all about dying, respawning on the spot and figuring things out. Interesting and varying riddles, although not too hard. I died at least once at almost every obstacle, before I knew what to expect. No high-skill, high-speed coordination over long sequences required, which is a good thing, since it can only be played with the arrow keys and Ctrl on keyboard. Move and grab, that’s all. Something like a vague world-explanation at the end, instead of a story. Took me about 6 hours.

132610570.review:
Limbo is a unique and atmospheric puzzle-platformer that is sure to delight fans of the genre and newcomers alike. This game is a true gem, and it's a must-play for anyone who loves a good challenge.

One of the standout features of Limbo is its minimalist and hauntingly beautiful aesthetic. The game's monochromatic world is both haunting and gorgeous, and it is sure to captivate players from beginning to end. And the game's sound design is equally impressive, with atmospheric ambient noises that enhance the game's atmosphere and add to the overall chill experience.

Another great aspect of Limbo is its well-designed and challenging puzzles. The game's puzzles are clever and rewarding, and they provide a real sense of accomplishment when completed. And with its tight controls and precise platforming, players are sure to feel a sense of satisfaction as they progress through the game's levels.

In addition to its great puzzles, Limbo is also a deeply atmospheric game. The game's world is both beautiful and mysterious, and players are sure to find themselves lost in its strange and haunting landscapes. And the game's lack of dialogue and narration only add to the game's eerie atmosphere, making Limbo a truly unique gaming experience.

In conclusion, Limbo is a must-play for anyone who loves puzzle-platformers and atmospheric games. With its hauntingly beautiful aesthetic, challenging puzzles, and eerie atmosphere, Limbo is sure to provide players with hours of entertainment and a true sense of chill. So if you're looking for a relaxing and captivating gaming experience, be sure to check out Limbo!

132341108.review: LIMBO is a must-play for anyone looking for a unique and atmospheric gaming experience. The game's visuals are stunning, with a monochromatic art style that perfectly captures the mood and tone of the game. The game's mechanics are simple, but effective, with a focus on puzzle-solving and exploration that keeps players engaged from start to finish. The game's sound design is also noteworthy, with an atmospheric and immersive soundscape that enhances the game's already haunting atmosphere. The game's length is short, but its impact is long-lasting, with a thought-provoking narrative that stays with players long after they have completed the game. Overall, LIMBO is a game that is not to be missed. Its unique visuals, engaging mechanics, and haunting atmosphere make it a game that is sure to please fans of puzzle and platforming games alike.

132338342.review:
Being the game that came before INSIDE and after playing both of them, you can clearly see a pattern here from Playdead and the foundations of what INSIDE became are really all there in LIMBO. 

It's mindblowing to me what LIMBO achieves with such "simple" scenarios and color scheme, I wrote "simple" because in the end LIMBO turns out to be one very complex game. 
The anxiety and slight fear that the game ambiance together with the soundtrack gave me was amazing, the puzzles are all very entertaining, eventually you'll have to make a bigger effort and think more on some of them but not a single one of them blocks you for a long period of time which makes the puzzles rewarding and enjoyable to get once you do so you can keep moving in the game. 

Much like INSIDE or should I say, INSIDE, much like LIMBO, passes a very good message and story with only gameplay, no words or cutscenes needed and you can theorize a lot but there's some things you can get really easy that are kind of set in stone in the story.

Overall an amazing experience, BUY IT, PLAY IT!

The game that kickstarted a whole new genre in gaming!
Limbo is a short, dark and gritty adventure about a boy who's trying to find his lost sister in limbo. Other than the one sentence you can see on Limbo's Steam page, we don't get any hints or dialogues on what the story is about.
The developers leave everything for the player's imagination, and the story is whatever makes the most sense to you. It's amazing how the game manages to capture a creepy and depressing vibe just from black and white colors and a simple soundtrack.
If you haven't played Limbo until now, I highly suggest that you do.

131677904.review:
[h1]Don't let the cool art style fool you. The rest of the game is not nearly as special and rather tedious than anything else.[/h1]

Limbo looks awesome. 
And the first few puzzles are actually clever and fun to solve.
End of good things to say about this.

The game is super short, and it has to be, because towards the end the puzzles and platforming get exceedingly frustrating, annoying and fiddly and by that time you've definitely seen more than enough of the creepy black and white imagery, so it can't distract you from the increasingly tedious gameplay any longer. Had it gone beyond the four hour mark, I would've probably just stopped playing it. I wouldn't have missed out on much anyway, since the ending is extremely unsatisfying and wtf. If only the game had anything resembling of a proper story or background to keep you interested and motivated all the way, it wouldn't be so pointless, but there is nothing except hollow symbolism and meaningless metaphors. 

Limbo prooves: Some video games can be considered art. Limbo prooves also: Some art is kind of sh*t. 
Way too expensive at full price (currently 10 Euros!), so if you really want to try this game, at least wait for 50% off to minimize eventual regret.

131438677.review:
Limbo es un juego que originalmente salió para PS3 y en su momento estaba catalogado como uno de los más recomendados del sistema.
A mi juicio casi podría asegurar que el juego fué hecho en Flash, pero para que gráficamente se diferenciara del resto decidieron hacerlo sumamente oscuro y atmosférico, jugada que les salió redondísima porque lograron crear algo atrapante y misteriosamente envolvente, creo que a partir de aquí se crea el género de plataforma de terror/noir sin ser necesariamente un survival.

Hay muchas cosas a resaltar de Limbo, como su jugabilidad simple de correr/saltar/agarrar y con esos 3 elementos ya estás listo para resolver puzzles que pueden ir desde lo sencillo hasta lo un tanto complicado, eso sí, como todo en este juego es implícito no se siente que se esté relatando una historia como sí sucedía con Inside, hay piezas que no encajan del todo, por lo que podríamos decir que aquí experimentaron con diversas formas de divertir y perturbar al mismo tiempo, por ende la historia aquí la mantuvieron sumamente sencilla para poder implementar cualquier cosa que no pudiese tener una explicación lógica, una forma bastante ingeniosa para ahorrarse al guionista.

En esta atmósfera todo es inexpresivo, el único atisbo de humanidad que podemos ver está en los ojos blancos de nuestro protagonista, que dicho sea de paso también es un niño, pero sus dos globos oculares hacen presencia ahí solo para decirnos que manejamos a un ser humano y es todo lo que vamos a ver hasta no llegar al final.

Los enemigos a veces son inexistentes, parece que solo somos nosotros en una naturaleza de formas exageradas donde son los insectos sin definir los que generan este escenario, mientras la mayor parte del tiempo hay escaleras, cajas, plataformas colgantes y algunas máquinarias tanto rurales como científicas.

Eso sí, todos estos elementos conforman varios puzzles a resolver, y es tal la cantidad de creatividad que le metieron aquí que con solo dos cajas son capaces de dejarte atascado durante horas antes de que te des cuenta que la solución necesitaba de un buen momento de reflexión y lógica.

Hay ocasiones en que aparecerán insectos parásitos que definen nuestra jugabilidad y donde somo podemos ir en una sola dirección sin ninguna otra decisión más que saltar y avanzar, pero siempre procurando hallar una fuente de luz natural que pueda derretirlos como si fueran ácido.

La duración del juego es muy relativo, se disfruta tanto que en un día podrías terminarlo, o por el contrario te puedes llegar a atascar tanto, que preferirás hacer otras cosas y dejarlo para otro día.

La parte final es una auténtica voladera de cabeza, no solo por estar bien ambientado sino porque supieron complementarse con los puzzles (que dicho sea de paso dejaron los más difíciles para el final), es sorprendente que el ultimo de ellos sea uno de los desafíos mas difíciles que se puedan llegar a resolver porque requiere coordinación, ritmo y precisión.

Para ser el primer juego con el que debuta Playdead debo decir que el trabajo es muy sobresaliente y recomendado sin lugar a dudas, lo que no deja de sorprenderme (aparte del hecho de que a pesar de haber cumplido 12 años en los que se sigue sosteniendo bien como todo buen clásico) es que no dejan de salir parches para arreglar problemas menores mientras siguen trabajando en su misterioso tercer juego del que espero tengamos cuando menos un trailer.

131238171.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

limbo is a side-scrolling puzzle-platformer developed by indie studio playdead and published for microsoft. it came out on the xbox 360 in july 2010, but was ported to PS3 in a year later july 2011, and PC in early august. the game uses physics that effect both objects in the environment and your player character. limbo has a minimalist art style which lets you focus on the gameplay.  even the controls are minimal, with movement left and right, jumping, and grabbing being the only four controls.

the game, while simple, is simplicity at it's best. limbo has a gloomy ambiance, helped by the fact that the only colors in this game are black and white. the plot is also nearly non-existent, but the game-play is what makes this game as treasured as it is. the puzzles are genuinely great and have tons of variety. the one thing i don't like about this game is how short it is, i can see people beating this game in 2 hours or so, but it also could take you up to around 5 hours depending on your skill. i definitely recommend this game, especially when it's on sale.

131111912.review: Plays perfectly on my Steam Deck.  I love this type of puzzle platformer, even if it's just black and white. 131111439.review:
Limbo is a really simple but challenging sideways scrolling puzzle game.
The graphics are grey scale but very smooth, and genuinely well done. Dark sinister cartoon style.
The controls are just 5 buttons.
There is no real combat or shooting, just exploration style puzzles.
What made this game really stand out for me was the sheer variety of puzzles.
Every puzzle is genuinely different and every section introduces new features.
Its very simple but you do not get bored.
Just one negative issue: it is a bit on the short side. Steam & Youtube videos show it being done in an hour. It took me only 4 hours to solve everything. OK so its an indie game, but I would still wait till its reduced in a sale before you buy to get some value for money.

Gloomy side-scrolling 2D platformer. Looks fantastically bleak and rounds up its ambiance with a haunting musical score. Its puzzles are very much based around trial and error, which can get grating after a while. There´s a sense of whimsy from the over the top deaths that this approach to puzzle-solving produces. It´s rather short so it never gets unbearably frustrating. 
Very pretty, kinda weird, solid physics-based 2D platforming, short enough to finish in one sitting, with some optional hidden collectibles for completionists. I'm not sure how much I got out of it as a work of art apart from its art design, but it´s a fun couple of hours.

130746721.review:
[I]Limbo[/I] is an interesting, straightforward puzzle-platformer. Most players should be able to get through the game within a couple of hours.

[I]Limbo's[/I] story is ambiguous, but it certainly has a unique charm with its stylized atmosphere, audio cues, and monochrome art direction. The game has a balanced approach to its puzzles where problem-solving skills and coordination skills comes into play. [I]Limbo[/I] is geared towards overcoming environmental hazards and dispatching several foes using logic and timing. The game, however, can be quite dark -- both in the literal and thematic sense. There are many gruesome deaths awaiting the nameless hero or his adversaries; and, there's even a whole (optional) section of the game played completely in the dark. A methodical approach is highly recommended. As such, this game may not be well-suited for the run-and-gun type of player but it can be an enjoyable distraction for those with a bit of patience. It's a decent game.

130255847.review:
First off, I need to preface that I am not a puzzle game fan, so these thoughts are definitely biased. It would be good to say that I dont have anything against this particular game, but this genre more generally (hence the positive review despite the subsequent complaining). Second, I clearly lack some creative-thinking component of my brain, because the puzzles seem so obvious in hindsight but I didnt have a hope in hell in solving them, and that absolutely influenced my experience of the game.

The atmosphere was quite nice though. The game has such a lonely feel to it, in a tranquil, peaceful sense (except for all the things trying to kill you). The game does a great job at making you feel small, and feel fairly helpless in the face of such ominous, imposing situations. The visuals are also striking and still unique to this day. I think the gore, and especially the fact that these were the violent deaths of a child, which are usually not depicted in media, helped this game get attention. The grey-scale means that things can stick out quite easily when the devs want it to (like sparks or brain-worms) which helps when recognizing affordances or pertinent points of information. Even when not white, important objects usually stick out very clearly against the background. I never had issues figuring out WHAT I should use to solve the puzzles, only HOW I should be solving them.

In my experience, this game had a healthy bit of ‘just blindly try stuff and see what happens’. The game has you replay the same section countless times (dying countless times) to learn slightly more about the puzzle each time, until you eventually figure it out.

And with all of this trial and error, I find it especially frustrating that when I know my fate is sealed (I know I am screwed and am going to die) the game really takes it sweet time delivering it. I die, slow animation, pause, slow fade to black, slow respawn. It feels like a lot of unnecessary waiting in between attempts, especially for a game that asks you to try the game jump 20 times to make it. I get that they are trying to produce an atmosphere and mood for the game, but it wasn't for me.

I found that the vagueness of the controls and the sometimes cryptic nature of the clues caused quite a frustrating experience. Because the movements (jumps specifically) require exquisite timing, the game often has you doubting yourself, and wondering if the solution you have found is really a solution at all (”Did I miss this jump because of my mistake, or is there something I am not considering that is needed to make this jump?”). It feels really frustrating to think that progress towards the whole game is impeded by a stupid jump that you feel like you should make but cant for variables that you cant account for, and cant influence. There were plenty of moments I felt like I was going to have an aneurysm because you are cm away from your goal but you miss the jump or something else goes wrong. Wait for the painfully slow fade to black and respawn, try again x50.

Example of some of the annoying quirks:
You have to hit a switch and then jump onto this rope before the platform that holds the rope moves too far out of your reach. First you try hitting the switch and then running to the rope to grab on before it moves away. That doesnt work. Okay, was it your timing? Was it something else? You don't know, no feedback.  Try ten more times to be sure. Go on YouTube, turns out you have to get the rope swinging before you jump. Okay, start swinging, try to jump off, no bitch, turns out you cant swing on the rope and jump down at the same time, that just stops the rope. Try again. Try to jump off. No bitch, because you have to shimmy down the rope now to get off, which stops the rope. Try again. Finally you figure it out. You get it swinging, jump off, turn on the switch, and after the 100th attempt you manage to land on the rope as its swinging in the correct position WHILE the platform is moving away from you. You try to jump off, no bitch, remember you have to shimmy down the rope. Because there is no jump, you kinda fall off the rope, right onto the obstacle you were trying to avoid in the first place, now time to repeat this all over again.

And my last though: the clues are extremely subtle, sometimes you cant be sure if it was just an animation or a clue. So you begin to interpret everything as potentially meaningful, which is probably the right move. Example: an insect’s slightest movement turned out to be a clue that he reacts to quick movement and that you should move slowly and gently. But you have to jump from exactly the right place to make it, which requires a bunch of attempts to find that magic spot to jump from. 

The game is frustrating because you feel like you have tried everything, then the answer is so obvious you feel stupid and that you wasted your time. I really don't think I would have gotten half as far as I did if it weren't for YouTube. 3/4 through the game I just gave up and watched the rest on YouTube play through to see if I missed anything

Turns out the story was also very vague and (deliberately) left open to interpretation.

Obviously this is a classic for some, but I just couldn't get into it

130249609.review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

129622441.review: A side-scrolling platformer filled with mind-bending physics puzzles, LIMBO is the story of a boy who wakes up alone in a strange and menacing forest filled with perils including giant spiders, claw traps, and rickety structures. Everything's presented in grayscale silhouettes and has a graininess that recalls old films. The only sounds heard throughout most of the game are the boy's footsteps, quiet ambient noises, and the occasional startlingly loud drone. It's in turn lonely, scary, beautiful, and arresting. The title suggests the setting is purgatory, though the world's intense isolation and manifold dangers makes it at times frightening enough to be confused with Hell.

128927872.review:
LIMBO drew me in with its really unique artstyle (and low price) but sadly even at that low pricepoint I can't really recommend the game. At the best of times LIMBO had me drawn in by the intense atmosphere it manages to create, but sadly when it did manage this it was fleeting, because I would soon be spat right back out of my immersion when encountering the next of the dozens of clunky, uninteresting and overfly finicky puzzles that litter this game. Although i have a respect for how LIMBO encourages you to both think outside the box and observe your environment, the "puzzles" too often end up as Meatboy-esque ripoffs of superior platformers which require overly precise timing and movement in a game that isn't built for such things. This comes to an absolute peak in the [spoiler]secret level[/spoiler] which isn't even puzzles anymore, just obnoxious platforming. Overall this game is a perfect example of the lovely english expression "don't judge a book by it's cover". It may look nice on the outside, but sadly there's very little substance holding this small game together. 
4/10

The overall design of the game and the plot makes you super aware of your surroundings in game, which can majorly help you in the gameplay. The game is full of entertaining puzzles, not hard to do but definately requiring a lot of thinking and in some chapters a few tries. The lack of a storyline may not be for everyone, but the game's mood and atmosphere more than make up for it. Overall, LIMBO is a must-play game for anyone looking for a unique and engaging gaming experience.

I am a 43 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you <3

126464006.review:
Limbo was an indie darling back in the late 2000s, one of the first small-scale releases that showed off what teams with lower budgets could do. It drew a lot of attention for its gloomy atmosphere and minimalist sepia-tone art style, a creative choice that still stands out today.

As for the gameplay, it's a basic 2D platformer with simple momentum and item-based puzzles. It's a lot like Portal in that regard and you'll be done with the game after three hours. If you're looking for something deeper, I wouldn't bother but those who are looking for a quick single-player title that sucks you in fully, it's an easy recommendation in the sales when it is often below £5.

125919475.review:
Playdead's debut is a really good mix of precision platforming, puzzle solving, and action sequences, with an engrossing visual style and a perfect audio presentation. Controls are tight, and every level is compulsively fine-tuned: if you fail (and you'll fail a lot) it's all your fault. You just need to observe every element and make the best of it. Limbo is one of the most gruesome games you can think of, and you'll witness that poor kid dying in the most cruel ways. Your job is to guide him safely until he finds his lost sister. Not an easy task, but really worth the effort. I love Limbo and it's atmosphere. I played it beginning to end a lot of times in almost every system available, and I know I'll come back to it in the future.

PS.- Look out for the secret level after you collect every egg: it's the meanest secret level of all time!

125395188.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Visuals are moody and minimalistic. The colors are various shades of gray; not a single hue to be found here
- The sound effects are similarly sparse. When there are auditory cues, they're either grating or eerie

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- There's no overt narrative. The player is left to infer what's going on from environmental cues (of which there are few)
- Everything in the world is hostile. You don't go very far without a trap, fall, or enemy attempting to kill you

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- The game is largely a platform puzzler. Beyond the moving platforms and switches that you'd expect as hallmarks of the genre, there's some interesting puzzle mechanics with sound, light, gravity and timing as well
- The only controls are jumping and grasping, so the only thing you have to solve puzzles besides those are your wits and the environment
- There's no real downside to dying unless you're trying to get a specific achievement, so failure is expected the first few attempts at most puzzles
- Exploration is also encouraged via hidden collectibles with accompanying achievements

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- It's a moody, dark, brooding, and atmospheric experience. The puzzle design's reliance on death mechanics serves to emphasize these themes
- I played the game in its entirety on the Steam Deck. It performed extremely well

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]9/10[/b]. I missed this game back when it was released, and I'm happy to have finally gotten around to play it. With all the great puzzle design and fantastically dark atmosphere, it's a must-play

125214992.review:
This is a good title. I worded that first sentence very carefully. So why am I giving it a negative rating? It's been in my library for literally years, probably from a Humble Bundle a decade ago, and I played it on my Deck because I can't imagine playing it on a big screen.

Simply put, they don't make platformers like they used to, which is why it went untouched. This is a fantastic art piece, often characteristic of a lot of very indie games, but as a game it's exceptionally shallow and gimmicky, also like a lot of indies. It's essentially a 2D walking simulator. The mood, the sound effects, the graphics, the animations, all on point. But as someone who is used to platformers of old from the likes of Apogee and Epic, it's a step backwards. Your mind wanders as you hold the (in my case) analog stick right for about half a minute until you get to the next puzzle/enemy, and it runs out of ideas pretty quickly.

I enjoy looking at it and hearing it, but it doesn't *do* anything of serious note with that mood.

I hear that Inside has a bit more going on. We'll see...

Overall, it's a pretty cool little puzzle game with unique visuals, so if you have a couple of hours and like puzzles, give it a go.
